column413:
Players are Arena-Fight managers who compete for the job of Overall Arena-Fight manager in Rome. They can get this job by supporting the right candidate for becoming Emperor.

Organizing Gladiator fights and entertaining the crowd will win the players money and the candidate they support Popularity Points. Whether a fight was a commercial success or not depends on the supporters of the Gladiator teams
column414:
because they get to vote after each fight (thumbs up or down) and losing supporters/gladiators will be ejected from the game.

Colorful counters
column429: Players assume the roles of the famous Arabian characters like Sinbad and Scheherezade and try to move merchants
column431: magi etc through the bazaar. By accumulating resource cards and selling them
column434: driving out lower ranking people and buying gems. The aim is to reach the palace with a diamond in your pocket
column435:
and pass it to the Vizier.

But the rules allow several winning conditions and players can even steal from your bag of gems
column436: making you buy fake gems to protect your diamond. The different roles make the resources have different values
column437: so Scheherazade prefers silks to weapons
column447: Fairy Meat is Kenzer & Company's acclaimed actual-size miniatures wargame of cannibal fairy combat. The once peaceful fairy folk have become addicted to fairy flesh
column448: and their world has plummeted into violent anarchy. Players control a warband of bloodthirsty fairies
column449:
hunting and killing for the flesh and blood of their own kin.

Fairy Meat is a very multi-player game
column450: for two or more mature gamers who want something different. The full-color rulebook includes cardstock fairy status cards
column452:
and stand-up fairy miniatures; a deck of cards and a ruler are all that's required for a lifetime of fairy-butchering fun!

Expanded by:

Fairy Meat: Clockwork Stomp

column461: How low can you go? In Zero
column462: you want to score as few points as possible
column463:
but to do that you need to collect the right cards in hand.

The deck consists of 56 cards
column464: with cards numbered 1-8 in seven colors. Each player starts with nine cards in hand
column466: seven or nine cards start face-up on the table depending on the number of players. On a turn
column467: you either knock on the table to pass or you swap one card in hand for one card on the table. After the second knock
column468: whether from the same player or a different one
column469: all players other than the second knocker have one final chance to swap
column470: after which they reveal and score their hands. If you have five or more cards of the same color or number in hand
column471: then those cards score 0 points. For each other number you have
column473: you score points equal to that card's value. Thus
column474:
having one to four 7s in hand is worth 7 points.

If
column476: you manage to collect both five cards of a color and five cards of a number in hand (with one card fitting in both sets)
column477: then you can declare "Zero!" and end the round immediately
column478:
with everyone else scoring points as usual.

After a number of rounds equal to the number of players
column479:
whoever has the lowest score wins!

FROM GAME CABINET review:
In the middle of the table is a pyramid of 'demand' cards. These cover a variety of subjects (hobbies
column491: and symbolize what the public wants to look at on the Web. The higher up the pyramid
column492: the stronger the demand. Over time these change
column493: and can even be reinforced - if the masses want cooking and nature
column494: you give it to them. The players each try to set up their web sites
column496:
to match the demand and draw in users.

column505:
It is a game where everyone simultaneously plays a unique number face down card a la Take 5 (6 Nimmt).

There are 5 suits arranged in a circular pattern. The idea is you score the points based on the first person to hit their number traveling clockwise after the current number
column506: e.g. if the colors are Green
column513: etc. and the current target card is Orange 6
column514: then the first number after orange 6 wins a number of points equal to the interval. For example
column516: but if it were not there and Green 1 were next closest
column517: it would win 5 points. If the next closest card were orange 5 (unlikely but possible)
column518:
it would score 49 points.

Each player also always has in hand a Shit! card which cannot score
column519:
but playing it is the only way to get another card in hand. Strategy comes from watching when people play cards and how many they have left. Time it right and you can play while everyone else is drawing for monster points.

It's a fun 20 minutes. The rules are in English.

""
column529: Bruno Faidutti revisits the medieval setting of Ohne Furcht und Adel with the card game Castle. Players are given a set of square cards which are to be played onto the table
column530: which has a cardboard castle battlement layout. Cards are played into one of four regions: in the courtyard
column533: or outside the castle. And when played
column534: the cards will usually allow you to take some sort of special action
column535: which is unique to the card you played. The first player to rid himself of all his cards wins
column536:
which can be a tricky proposition at best.

A winner of the 2000 Concours International de Créateurs de Jeux de Société.

""
column547: A pure bluffing game. Each player gets a set of cards numbered 1 to 8 and a playing mat
column548: which goes in front of him or her. The starting player is the Baron and the other players in turn offer him a card face down from their hand
column549: stating the value. Each player must offer an equal or higher value card than the last and the Baron must take the highest card offered or choose between equal offers. The Baron must then decide to Accept or Reject the offer. If he accepts
column550: the Baron puts the card face down on his mat and the turn passes to the next player. But if the Baron decides the player was lying and Rejects the offer
column551: he turns the card over. If the offer was False
column552: the player takes it back to their hand and the Baron gets to dump one of his cards onto his mat. But if it was True
column553: The Baron must take the card into his hand and the player dumps a card face down. When a player's hand is empty
column554: the game is over and you total the value of the cards on your mat
column555: subtracting any left in your hand. Highest score wins. A simple game of pure bluff
column556: it works incredibly well. Very funny and requires some thought. Baron Muenchausen is a famous character from German folklore
column557: a notorious liar who lived a fantastical life. The game mats show illustrations and stories from his life in German
column558:
but this has nothing to do with the actual game play and non-German readers can play the game easily.

""
column566:
From session report:
A card game. The deck consists of five different colored sets of cards
column567: each set numbered 1 - 8. There are  also five matching sets of wooden disks
column568:
10 of each color.

The cards are dealt out equally to the players and they alternate playing one card face-up to the table. Unlike a trick-taking game
column569: there is no need to follow suit; players may play any card they desire. If a player lays a card of the same color and a LOWER value as a previously laid card that round
column570: the higher card is turned over and is out of play. When play returns to a player who still has his card face-up in front of him
column571: he collects a number of chips from the stockpile which matches the number and color of the card he played. If his card is face-down
column573: he does not collect any chips. In either case
column574:
he plays another card and the cycle continues until the players have played all of their cards.

When collecting chips
column575: if the stockpile of a certain color is depleted
column576: the player then steals the required number and color of chips from the opponent who currently possesses the most chips of that color. Thus
column577:
each player's collection of chips is constantly in danger of being confiscated by their opponents.

The basic rules call for a number of rounds equal to the number of players
column578:
with the player collecting the greatest cumulative total of chips over those rounds being the victor.

""
column587: with three colored suits (cards from 1 to 20)
column588: and the possibility of trumps or no-trumps.   You have to bid for which suit (or suits) you think you will capture most cards of
column589: or you can bid to capture fewer cards than anyone else.   Get it right
column591: you take a penalty.   The number of cards per hand increases round by round
column592:
and the number of rounds depends on the number of players.

From the Box:
Where's Bob's Hat? is best with 3 or 4 players. Over several hands
column593: players bid to take the most cards in one or more of the three suits
column594: each a different kind of hat. Players who feel they will take few
column596:
tricks may bid to take the fewest cards in tricks played during each hand. Players score points for making their bids and lose points for missing their bids.

Several cards picture Bob's Hat in addition to the hat of their suit. When a player wins a trick containing a card with Bob's Hat on it
column597:
the player takes the Bob's Hat card (worth plus or minus 10 points). The player with the card at the end of the hand add (or subtracts) 10 points to his score. The player with the most points at the end of the game is the winner!

""
column606: A two player card game depicting the siege of a castle. One player is the defender and the other is the attacker. Players play cards and roll dice to try and tear down the walls of the castle or repell the invaders.
column615: Shift is basically a sliding-tile puzzle for up to four players.  The board is a 6x6 grid
column616: with an extra row of 6 on each side to serve as a home base
column617: for a total of 60 squares.  Each player has 12 tiles in his color
column618: plus an extra 11 white tiles to fill out the board.  On his turn
column619: a player makes six shifts to the puzzle
column620: attempting to move his tiles across the board.  The winner is the first person to move six of his pieces into the home base across from him.  With four players
column621:
the game can also be played in partnership.

""
column633: this game features a battery-powered central drum
column634: which spins color-coded targets around its perimeter.  Each of the players has a little color-coded archer character that shoots plastic darts at the central drum.  If you aim well
column635:
you'll hit one of the targets and a spring-loaded mechanism will make the target pop out of the drum. The object of the game is to be the last person with any of your colored targets left.

""
column643: The game uses a ring numbered from 1 to 40 with sliders on it. At the start
column644: the sliders are set randomly (by card draw). On your turn
column646: then play a "gapper" if possible (a gapper is a card falling between the numbers where the sliders rest
column647: as indicated by the sliders' arrowheads)
column649:
moving a slider to the discards number. There are wild cards in the deck.

If a player goes out
column650:
he wins 5 points plus one point per card still held by the other players. 25 points wins the game.

""
column659: Each player vies for control of the constellations which are worth victory points. There are 12 constellations and players use "Stars" to bid for the control. Each star is worth some amount of control over the constellation
column660:
and there is a "Double" star and a "Black Hole" star thrown into the mix. There is some aspect of bluff in the game since some of your stars may be placed face up or down.

""
column671: A light card game involving the build-up and destruction of medieval towns. In the "Prosperity" phase
column672: players attempt to build up their populations via stealing from other players or via improvements. Then the Death Ship arrives bearing the plague! In the "Plague" phase
column673: players attempt to kill other players by playing war
column675:
or other deadly attacks. The cards contain illustrations reminiscent of medieval woodcuts featuring the Grim Reaper.

""
column694: Starship Troopers is based upon the popular novel of the same name written by the dean of Science-Fiction writers
column695: Robert A. Heinlein. In the novel
column696: Heinlein describes a futuristic war involving homo sapiens from our Earth (Terrans) against a Humanoid race (nicknamed the 'Skinnies' for obvious physical attributes) and their cobelligerents
column697: the totally alien Arachnids. Since this is a story of future wars and future advances in technology
column698: much is changed in the fields of weaponry and tactics and strategy. One thing remains the same
column699: however; the fighting still rests on the shoulders of the individual infantryman. Although great starships has shuttle men between the distant solar systems and the power of individual weapons has risen to awesome heights
column700: wars still cannot be won unless men venture onto the face of alien planets and fight the enemy on their home ground. As Juan Rico
column702:
relates:

"We are the boys who go to a particular place
column706: dig the enemy out of their holes
column707: force them then and there to surrender or die. We're the bloody infantry
column710:
the foot soldier who goes where the enemy is and takes him on in person."

Although the mission remains the same
column711: future inventiveness has changed the method considerably. In a galaxy-wide war
column712: manpower is at a premium. Platoons fight where entire armies once tred. But these platoons possess the firepower equivalence of a Twentieth-Century mechanized division. More importantly
column713:
each man in the platoon is provided with a piece of hardware that allows him to fight and survive in the holocausts of future combat—his powered armor suit. As Rico describes it:

"A suit isn't a spacesuit — although it can serve as one. A suit is not a space ship but it can fly—a little . . . Suited up
column714: you look like a big steel gorilla
column715: armed with gorillasized weapons. But the suits are considerably stronger than a gorilla. If a Mobile Infantry man in a suit swapped hugs with a gorilla
column717: crushed; the man and the suit wouldn't be mussed . . . The real genius in the design is that you don't have to control the suit
column720: like skin . . . Even riding a bicycle demands an acquired skill
column721:
very different from walking. But a suit you just wear."

With the suit and the incredible array of weaponry that go with it
column722: the Mobile Infantry soldier is an exceedingly formidable opponent. He had better be. The enemies he faces are the most awesome adversaries in the galaxy. Of the two extraterrestrial races fighting the Terrans
column723:
the Humanoids are the least revolting. Rico describes them as

" . . . humanoid
column725:
much skinnier than we are and with a higher body temperature; they don't wear any clothes and they stand out in a set of 'snoopers' like a neon sign."

In early scenarios they are fighting on the side of the Arachnids. In later scenarios
column727:
they switch over to the Terran side. They're only effective fighters within the confines of their small city terrain and strong points on the board.

But the 'Skinnies' were mild looking in comparison to the Arachnids:

"The 'Bugs' are not like us. The Pseudo-Arachnids aren't even like spiders. They are arthropods who happen to look like a madman's concept of a giant
column731: is more like that of ants or termites; they are communal entities
column732:
the ultimate dictatorship of the hive . . . But don't make the mistake of thinking that they act purely from instinct . . . their actions are as intelligent as ours (stupid races don't build spaceships!) and were much better coordinated. It takes a minimum of a year to train a private to fight and to mesh his fighting with his mates; a Bug warrior is hatched able to do this ..."

As the Arachnid Player
column733: uses an Alien Control Pad sheet to record the placement of his underground central Hive cell complex and the attached tunnels radiating outward. Tunnels are used to move the Warrior units
column734: along with Worker units mixed in as expendable decoys
column735: to locations where they can pop up to the surface through a breach hole and attack the Terran units.  Completely unseen
column737: Engineer units are used to create the breaches and
column739:
to extend the tunnels.

The game is set up in a "Programmed Instruction" system of scenarios to slowly introduce the game concepts. Scenarios range from Scenario I
column740: which starts players off with a basic MI raid on a Skinny city (just like the book. "Flores died on the way up") to Scenario VII
column741:
The Battle of Klendathu: the final Terran assault on the Arachnid Homeworld.

Warfare in the Twenty-second Century is the ultimate test of survivability of the human race. It was a very near thing.

Avalon Hill Complexity rating - 5

""
column746: Bull Run: The First Major Battle of the American Civil War
column758:
"Bull Run: The First Major Battle of the American Civil War" is a tactical combat wargame of the first battle of Bull Run.

The game is played on a map of the area over which the battle was fought overlaid with a hexagonal grid. Units are infantry
column763: and army leaders. Each turn is 30 minutes
column764: and each hex represents 1000 ft. Units are basically regiments and batteries. Some infantry regiments with their brigade leader are capable of forming brigades
column765: increasing offensive power at the expense of movement. Batteries can be limbered for increased movement at the expense of firepower
column766:
or unlimbered with full firepower and limited movement.

Combat is a modified version of the classic system adopted by the earlier Avalon Hill games. However
column769: and infantry forming brigades to prevent soak-off attacks
column771:
rally of losses are give the game a unique flavour.

The major terrain obstacle is Bull Run which provides the Confederate with defensive advantages and hinders Union movement.
The game begins with the Union troops approaching partially hidden
column772: unsuspecting Confederate forces.  As the Union attack develops
column773:
additional Confederate leaders and combat units are activated and are rushed to stem the Union advance. The Union player wins if he is able to capture any of three objective hexes by the end of the game or takes Manassas at any time. The Confederate player wins if he takes Centreville at any time or prevents the Union player from holding any of objective hexes at the game end.

The game consists of a 32" by 22" mapboard
column776:
a 12 page rulebook and 1 die.

""
column799:
from user review:
Each player assumes the role of a intra-galactic merchant
column800: traveling from planet to planet in a future where wars are unheard of and "Traders" are the heroes of the cosmos. The board shows 36 planets: six clustered together in the center of the board
column801: six more in each of five arms of the galaxy. Planets are connected by "jump lines": you can jump to an adjacent planet on an orange line
column802: to a planet halfway down a galaxy arm on a purple line
column803: and from one galaxy arm to another via green lines. The length of the jump line also indicates the difficulty of the jump
column804: so to successfully complete an "orange' jump you must roll a 2 or better on a single die
column805: a purple jump requires a 4 or better
column806:
and the green jumps necessitate a 6.

As the players scurry about the galaxy
column807: they can pick up and deliver cargoes
column808: which pay both in money and in "Prestige." These "contracts" vary throughout the game
column809: and only one player can fulfill any given contract. This isn't to say that multiple players can't pick up the named cargo
column810: though. But only the first player to arrive at the contract's destination gets the payoff for a contract; everyone else with the cargo is now just stuck with unwanted junk
column811: and may have to pay a penalty to dump it. Players can also build bases on the various planets as they move around. Building bases earns the players Prestige
column812: and when a player tries to make a jump to a planet with a base
column813: the jump is an automatic success if the player has the owner's permission. Traders obviously have permission to jump to their own bases
column814: but if they want to jump to an opponent's
column815: they will probably have to pay a fee. And since only one player can have a base on any given planet
column825: Space combat game where players expand their empire to achieve the most build points.  Build points are gathered by sending diplomatic fleets to charted
column826: but unexplored worlds.  Diplomacy results in the development of allies..or the gaining of enemies.  Combat between the individual players (or enemy worlds) is conducted by deploying fleets of ships.   The system offers variant game play
column827:
endings and even a solitaire format.

From the publisher:

Introducing Evil Polish Brother's
column830:
the new standard in space conquest board gaming.

The object: dominate the galaxy through conquest and diplomacy.

Up to 4 players can Justify their Use of Military Power and rules are provided for true solo play.

Easy to learn game mechanics and fog-of-war adds to JUMP's addictive game play that will please the most avid wargamer and hook beginning gamers.

With moveable map tiles
column832: random generation tables and variant victory conditions
column833:
no game ever plays the same way twice.

JUMP: Into the Unknown is also ideal as a campaign setting for players of tactical space miniature combat games to stage their battles.

Each game comes with 3 map boards
column835: 200 foil stamped game pieces on solid black cardboard
column840:
and 1 rule book.

Designed as a Core System
column846: additional pieces to accommodate 4 more players
column860: 4th Dimension is a very spacey-looking game with a small circular board divided into sectors each track of which has twice as many spaces as the one closer to the center. Each player get 6 warriors
column863:
and one time lord. Guardians can capture warriors and rangers; rangers can capture warriors; the time lord can capture rangers and guardians; but the lowly warriors are the only ones who can capture the time lord and win the game. Captures are made by moving next to rather than on top of enemy pieces. Each piece can move only one space at a time but they can also "warp" by leaving the board and leaving a 4-D marker behind. The piece can then stay in the warp zone for up to three turns or warp back onto the board up to two spaces away from the 4-D marker. This game has an inconveniently small gameboard and plastic pieces that look like little futuristic chairs.

The game was first published in Games & Puzzles magazine. The designers produced it as a standalone game later the same year
column864:
and it was later licensed by TSR.

""
column873: Proudly touted as a "NON-collectable card game
column874: " Ninja Wars is a simple battle game with single die rolls determining victory. Each player gets three town cards of identical strength and five randomly dealt hero cards with values ranging from 1 to 5. Players are dealt hands of five action cards they can use to attack players towns and heroes or to strengthen their own heroes and towns. Gold cards are also in the action deck which allow players to bolster the value of an attack card. Battling players each roll a die and add the  scores of either their attack and gold cards (for the attacker) or the hero/town and training cards (for the defender). Play is simple and quick for a battle card game. The randomly assigned heroes can create unfair situations
column883: Before they can roll and move
column884: players must pick a card and present the rest of the players with a nasty choice between two thoroughly unpleasant hypotheticals in categories such as pain
column887: and ingestion. If the player guesses the majority preference
column888: he gets to move otherwise he must pass. Some spaces allow the player to invent their own awful hypothetical choice. The other players vote secretly on their choice in this case. If the vote is not unamimous
column889: the player can move or send someone else back. Players roll a six-sided die and there are only 10 spaces to the goal so games go very quickly. Typical choices on the cards include
column890:
"Would you rather lie naked in a bathtub full of live roaches or dive head first into a pool of tobacco spit?" The answer "neither" is NEVER allowed.

Variant:
The 2003 version of this game "Would You Rather?" appears to have quite different rules to the above described game. There is a new simpler square board with more spaces. Unlike the 20 minutes of the above game
column891: 1-2 hours is recommended by the manufacturer. Players roll a dice
column892: then move and depending where they land
column893: draw cards with dilemmas to pose to the rest of the other players. The current player must try to secretly predict the result of the other players' subsequent open discussion and consensus view. No-one is penalised for an inability to reach consensus
column894: the game encourages one option picked at random perhaps by flipping a coin
column895: to keep the game moving. If the current player predicted correctly
column896:
they get a bonus turn.

Typical questions include "Would you rather ... On senior prom night
column897:
have to take your parent -OR- your 12 year old sibling?"

Every so often players get the opportunity to take a difficult challenge with the winner being the first person to complete their third challenge.

""
column905: X-it! is simple mix of "Spite and Malice" (aka Skip-Bo) and solitaire mechanics. There are two decks which each have four suits with 20 cards in each suit. One deck is used to establish a large tableau on a circular gameboard which has 26 card slots around the circumference and four slots forming a central "X".  The second deck also contains 8 wild cards. Seven cards are dealt to each player from this second deck. The goal is to lay off all the cards in your hand onto one or more of the four "X" cards. The twist is you must be able to dump your entire hand on a single turn. In lieu of this option
column906: a player must try to play a card onto one of the 26 ring cards. Ring and "X" cards must first be "opened" by playing the exact same card on it. After this
column907: cards of any suit may be played on open cards in runs of ascending or descending order. At the end of a turn
column908: a player must play a card even if he was able to discard. If a player puts a card into a run that could have been used to open a card
column909:
he loses a turn and must take a penalty card from the player who catches him in the act.

""
column920:
Minion Hunter is the simplified board game version of GDW's Dark Conspiracy RPG.

Players move around the outer edge of the board trying to build up their cash
column922: equipment and four categories of ability points. In the middle of the board is a map of the USA and a progression track of Dark Minion plots represented by cards
column923:
which have city names on the backs and monster names and attack scores on the fronts.

Once players are strong and rich enough
column924: they can enter the map and fight the enemies shown on the cards that are currently on the track. The enemy cards move down the track after every player turn. If they reach completion
column928:
or Fey) gains points toward taking over America.

Players must boost their own success scores while also cooperating to keep the Dark Minions from snatching victory from all players.

Expanded by:

Minion Nation


""
column942:
This game should not be confused with the grail game Dune which has the same name (but is based on the book rather than the movie).

Based on the movie
column943: this version of Dune features photos of the stars on pawns divided into teams of three. Each character has its own strength and guile values. Players can move around the outer desert spaces to harvest monetary units of spice or can move around the inner castle spaces to build up strength. Players can use spice to buy random equipment cards
column945: or extra boosts of guile when under attack. Players can also invest in the craps-like commodity markets that pay off on certain dice rolls. The artwork is slick
column946: the rules are relatively simple compared to AH's version
column947:
and games go fairly quickly since all fights are to the death.

""
column959: Quarto has a 4×4 board and 16 pieces. Each piece has four dichotomous attributes — color
column962: and consistency — so each piece is either black or white
column965:
and hollow or solid. The object is to place the fourth piece in a row in which all four pieces have at least one attribute in common. The twist is that your opponent gets to choose the piece you place on the board each turn.

A winner of the 1985 Concours International de Créateurs de Jeux de Société.

""
column974: A "time-travelling" 4-dimensional chess variant played on a grid of 16 miniature chessboards. Each player has 2 rooks and 2 bishops
column975: each in its own warm or cool color. As each piece moves
column976: it literally leaves a paper trail of cardboard chits showing its progress through the game. A piece can be captured at any point on its timeline by landing on a square containing a chit
column977: and any actions taken since then by that piece are reversed. In this way a piece can capture an opposing piece 'earlier' than when that piece captured a friendly piece
column978:
thereby returning the friendly piece to the board. The game continues until all four opposing pieces have been captured.

""
column989: Rummy for Monopoly fans! Every property on the board has a card for you to collect to form at least one complete set. There are also house
column990: hotel and token cards to multiply the value of your sets. Mr. Monopoly and GO! Cards provide quick points and help fill out the 10-card hand in a 4-player game. Instead of a discard pile
column991:
each player has his own trade pile. Players can draw from the deck or exchange their trade piles with other players (whether they like it or not). A stack of money is included but is unnecessary since cash is only used to keep score and cannot be spent or exchanged.

""
column1002: Marrakesh was designed by Prince Joli Kansil of Hawaii
column1004: the two-handed bridge game. Marrakesh is an odd amalgam of backgammon and cardplay which works remarkably well. Each player sets up six pieces on their board based on the roll of six dice. Each player is dealt a hand of six cards from a special deck
column1005: and then try to collect two card tricks
column1006: using the card values to bear off the pieces. Points are awarded for bearing off pieces in various combinations
column1007: such as 2 on each of three turns
column1009: when all six pieces are borne off on the same turn. Defensive points are earned for keeping the opponent from removing many pieces from their board. Play continues for 12 rounds
column1010: which goes by quickly. This game is long out-of-print
column1011:
but well worth it if you can find it.

""
column1020: An interesting little game that uses a miniscule deck of 28 cards
column1021: consisting of 2 identical suits of Sun and Moon cards. Each partnership takes the part of either the Sun or Moon cult
column1022: and plays cards only of its designated suit. An interesting mechanic is that since the cards are dealt randomly
column1023: it is often necessary and even prudent to have an opponent play a card for you. The object of the game is to collect souls (of either cult) and temples of your own suit (which serve as a multiplier). Rounds move quickly
column1024: and points can add up dramatically.  (Description from original incarnation
column1034: players use runners to move on the board. On a turn
column1036: making one turn and placing a block on the turning space. If he can
column1037:
the player may also capture enemy blocks. The player may also place one blockade. Players score points for captured blocks and for the value of the spaces their blocks occupy. The player with the most points wins.

Re-implements:

Winkeladvokat


""
column1048:
This game is included as an insert game in Strategy & Tactics magazine #116; errata appears in S&T #117.

Manchu is a two player wargame covering the Taiping Rebellion that occurred in Manchu China between 1850 and 1868. The game is strategic in scale
column1049: and units are generic strength points representing Taiping rebels
column1052:
bandits and Mongolian cavalry. The game map represents Manchu China.

The Taiping player starts at an advantage in troops and leaders and seeks to conquer enough of the country to force a collapse of the Manchu government. The Manchu player seeks to survive the Taiping onslaught
column1053: and gains strength as the provincial forces are brought to bear.  However
column1054: over-reliance on provincial forces will cause a reduction of Imperial authority
column1055:
and that in itself may cause the game to be lost.

The game consists of a map
column1057:
rules and numerous charts.

A remake The Dragon and The Cross was published in 2018.

""
column1066: Dubble Kross uses a regurlar deck of cards
column1068: 11 plastic pegs and a house-shaped pegboard. Cards 2 through Queen each have a track on the board. Kings
column1069: aces and jokers are used as special action cards. After dealing out all the cards
column1070: four dice rolls determine the four penalty numbers. Any one who has the corresponding cards in their hands must pay to the kitty. In phase two
column1071: each player rolls the dice and either advances the corresponding peg on the board or pays more to the pot if the a penalty number is rolled. Like Parker Bros. "Can't Stop"
column1072: the length of each track is proportional to the probability of the roll. Therefore
column1073: the  "7" peg must travel the greatest distance while the "2" and "12" (Queen) pegs need only travel three spaces to win. When a peg crosses the finish line unchallenged
column1074:
each corresponding card in players' hands are worth a quarter of the pot.

""
column1086: "Singapore" is a two player wargame covering the Japanese invasion of the British Malaya in World War 2.  The game is operational in scale
column1087: with units representing brigades and regiments.  The mapsheet consists of two maps
column1088: a large scale map of Malaya as well as a more detailed map of Singapore island.  The earlier turns of the game takes place on the larger Malayan map
column1089: and play moves to the smaller Singapore map only towards the end of the game
column1090:
when the Japanese prepare to assault the island.

Game components consist of one mapsheet
column1103: In this game each player takes the role of a caravan leader. The number of camels within a caravan depends on the number of players. Each camel is loaded with a lot of goods
column1104:
and the goal of the game is to carry all the goods from the starting position to the final oasis: Timbuktu.

However
column1105: during the course of this journey
column1106: the caravans stop at other oases. Once all camels arrive at an oasis
column1108: thieves attack the caravan and steal different goods. While moving from one oasis to another
column1109: players receive different clues about the nature of the thefts. Each player has a different clue
column1110: and although clues are passed around
column1111: only one player receives three of the total five clues. From the actions of the other players (caravan leaders)
column1112: the clues have to be guessed and camels have to be relocated
column1113:
in order to save all the goods from the thieves.

The next morning
column1114: the caravan continues its way towards Timbuktu
column1115:
and players are challenged with different clues again. The object of the game is to be the trader left with the most value in goods when they arrive at Timbuktu.

""
column1128: Wizard Kings is an exciting fantasy battle game with armies of elves
column1134:
amazon). Players customize their armies and fight for control of strategic cities and terrain on geomorphic maps. Wizard Kings 2nd edition is a re-release of the sold-out 1st edition.

Wizard Kings can play in as little as one hour or be used as part of a miniatures campaign for months. Victory conditions vary with the many possible scenarios. The new version is multi-player out of the box. A collectible expansion blockset has been released at the same time.

Wizard Kings 2nd edition includes 4 new maps
column1135: which are compatible with existing maps from the first edition. There are many new unit types and artwork
column1136:
although first edition units remain valid for play.

Expanded By:

Wizard Kings: Expansion Armies
Wizard Kings: Expansion Maps

column1144: This abstract strategy doesn't really use the Fibonacci sequence (1
column1151: but it's pretty cool nonetheless.  The first player starts off with one move
column1154:
and so on up to a maximum of six moves. The object of the game is to surround your opponent's base with your six strike pieces. Everytime you get a strike piece adjacent to your opponent's base they lose 1 move point.

""
column1165: The Big Idea is a quick and easy card game (Cheapass style) where the players represent venture capitalists creating companies (from a noun card and an adjective card - "Erotic Pants") to take through the process of an IPO. You automatically gain a share in companies you create
column1166: and later you have opportunities to secretly invest in a company and publicly buy a share in a company. Finally
column1167: you roll a die to see which companies go public in a round: equal to or lessor than the shares issued in the company. And the pay out: based on the number of shares issued and the number of cards used in forming the company times the die roll.  The game is fairly simplistic
column1168: but it's lots of fun to create names of products like "Mentholated Chicken"
column1169:
while agonizing over helping your opponent because their product will net you the biggest gain.

Expanded by:

The Big Idea: More Cards! (compatible only with Semi-Deluxe edition)


Re-implemented by:

The Big Idea


""
column1183: one top secret briefcase and eight greedy spies that anyone can control. The object is to move the briefcase to your headquarters. Players can either secretly pay off or openly move a spy one space on their turn. Each player has an account of $10
column1184: 000 and can bribe spies in increments of at least $100. If you move a spy
column1185: another player may challenge the move. The two players then slowly reveal how much money they each have on the spy in question. If the challenger wins
column1186: the move is rescinded. If the defender wins
column1187: the move stays and the challenger loses his next turn. Players need to cooperate against whichever player is closest to victory. You can conspire openly to swipe the case or murder a spy and turn the tables on a player who is a mere one space away from winning. No dice
column1189:
no luck involved. Learn to work together or games will end in a hurry.

Amigo version (Casablanca) published 1991 supports 8 players.

""
column1198: in which players try to accumulate twenty "Goth Points" while giving their opponents cards that subtract Goth points. "Infection Points
column1202: also come into play along with Goth points
column1203:
so most of the cards are a mixed bag.

column1224: HeroQuest is Milton Bradley's approach to a Dungeons & Dragons-style adventure game.  One player acts as game master
column1225: revealing the maze-like dungeon piecemeal as the players wander.  Up to four other players take on a character (wizard
column1228:
or barbarian) and venture forth into dungeons on fantasy quests. Plastic miniatures and 3-D furniture make this game very approachable. Expansions were also released for this system.

The HeroQuest series consists of the main game and a number of expansions.

This game was made in cooperation with Games Workshop who designed the miniatures and helped in many of the production details including background world and art in the rule book and scenario book.

Additional material which is generally missed since it is not technically an expansion was published in the HeroQuest: Adventure Design Kit which did feature one more Heroquest adventure: A Plague of Zombies.

column1259: Battle Masters is a fantasy miniatures battle game by Milton Bradley
column1260: presumably licensed from Games Workshop.  The sizeable game box comes stuffed with tons of plastic miniatures
column1261:
a deck of combat cards and some dice. Players move and fight their armies based upon what card is turned over from the deck. Combat is held on a large vinyl mat 4.5 ft square (Actual Measurements: 55 inches by 57 inches).

From the back of the box:

Welcome to the world of Battle Masters - the epic game where you command mighty armies locked in a legendary conflict of good versus evil!

The noble Imperial Army is ready to meet the Forces of Chaos. You and your opponent must strategically guide 25 army units
column1263: across the gigantic 4 1/2' X 5' Battle Mat. Beware! Ditches
column1265:
river fords and the great Border Tower lie before you.

The battle unfolds as each turn of a Battle card tells which army units can move and which can attack. Will your army be victorious
column1266: or will your opponent destroy you? Who will survive the battle and win the game? The fate of the Empire is decided by you
column1267:
the Battle Masters!

column1289: A House Divided: The American Civil War
column1297:
from Mayfair Games website:

A House Divided simulates the epic struggle of the American Civil War that was fought over the twin issues of slavery and state's rights. The period from 1840 to 1861 saw these issues brought to a boil
column1298:
and in 1861 the nation became tangled in a terrible war that lasted four long years.

The game depicts the war between North and South from the First Battle of Bull Run (or Manassas Junction) to Lee's surrender at Appomattox Courthouse – or Grant's surrender at Harrisburg... Each player leads one of these two nations and makes the strategic decisions which determine the outcome of the war.

The game board represents the United States
column1299: north and south and from the Atlantic coast to just west of the Mississippi. [...] The play map contains a number of boxes
column1301: town or locations important to the war. These boxes are connected by transportation lines – blue for rivers
column1302:
tan for roads and black for railroads – which provide the paths to victory or defeat.

Can you keep the Union whole or force the separation of the United States?

""
column1315: others play Wabbits. All players battle for points: plowing fields in Spring (even the Wabbits!)
column1318: and destroying buildings in Winter. Think Elmer Fudd and Bugs Bunny fighting over the operation of a farm.  Just like in the cartoons
column1319:
players can mail away for items to help them in squashing the other players.

Followed by:
Wabbit's Wevenge

""
column1330: Roman Civil War is a two player wargame covering the battles between Pompey and Julius Caesar. The game is strategic in scale
column1332: fleets and allied units on both sides. The mapsheet
column1334: covers the important areas of the Roman empire
column1337: Asia and Egypt. Off-board areas represent surrounding areas such as Spain
column1338:
Gaul and Syria.

Game components consist of a mapsheet
column1351: Each player tries to fly his balloon as high as possible. For this
column1352: he is equipped with ballast which can be dumped at the right opportunity
column1353: grappling hooks for linking to other balloons
column1354: soporific gas for knocking out balloons below
column1355:
and a super motor. Players can also use tempest cards to reverse the game play.

Extrapolated From Balloning Games: Each player starts with an identical set of cards
column1356: chooses a random subset and adds one card each turn. The higher the card played
column1357: the more likely one is to move up
column1358: but there are other interesting plays such as grappling onto another balloon
column1359: using soporific gas on lower balloons or storms which defeat the leaders. It can be especially interesting to compete against the non-player Black Baron who has been known to win the game from time to time
column1365: Caesar in Gallia: Conquest on the Ancient Frontier
column1370: Caesar in Gallia is a two player wargame covering Julius Caesar's conquest of Gaul. The game is strategic in scale
column1373: barbarian warbands and allied troops. The mapsheet
column1375: covers an area corresponding approximately to Britain. France
column1378:
Spain and parts of Africa. An off-board box is used to represent the Italian homeland.

Game components consist of a mapsheet
column1385: Frederick the Great: The Campaigns of The Soldier King 1740-1763
column1396: Frederick the Great is an operational level wargame on the Seven Years War between Frederick the Great's Prussia (and allied Hanover) and the anti-Prussian coalition consisting of France
column1398:
Russia and a host of European countries.

There are seven scenarios
column1399:
each covering one year of campaigning.

The game consists of a map covering most of central Europe
column1400:
rules and counters depicting the important leaders and generic strength points representing armies.

""
column1409: When Tiger Fight: The War in Asia
column1411:
is a strategic level wargame of the battles that were fought on the Chinese front during the latter stages of World War 2. The map covers a large portion of mainland China and parts of Burma.

Game Scale:
Turn: 1 month
Map: 37.2 miles / 60 km per hex
Unit: Regiment to Army

Game Contents:
One 22 x 34" map
Two countersheets (100 5/8" dual-side printed counters - 81 of them are errata for other games)
One 32 page rulebook
One Player Aid Card (2-sided)

""
column1422: "Holy War: Afghanistan" is a two-player wargame covering the war in Afghanistan between the communist regime supported by Soviet troops and equipment
column1423: and the Afghan Resistance. The game is strategic in scale
column1424: with units representing divisions and brigades. Aspects of the war covered in the game include conventional and guerilla warfare
column1425:
politics and the possibility of foreign intervention.

The game includes a campaign and several shorter scenarios. Game components include 22" by 17" map
column1438: Dragons of Glory is a simple wargame set in the fantasy world of the Dragonlance fantasy series.  Players take the roles of the the evil Dragon Highlords who try to conquer the nations of Ansalon
column1440:
who try to stop the Dragon Highlords. Game consists of four scenarios and a campaign game.

The game system is built around the standard wargame
column1442: counters representing the armies and fleets of both sides and the leaders who led them
column1443: combat charts.  The turn sequence is the standard you-move-I-move kind.  One interesting thing about the game is that both players start with minimal forces (The Whitestone player actually starts with none!)
column1444:
and try to activate allied nations as the game progresses.

Game component consists of one mapsheet depicting the continent of Ansalon in the fantasy world of Krynn
column1457: One player assumes the role of a single Bolotomus
column1458: fighting off an infestation of Snits.  The other player commands the Snit onslaught
column1459: attempting to ravage the Bolotomus's internal organs. The battles are between the Bolotomus' immune system and the Snits; the Bolotumus player controls immobile Snorgs (organs) and mobile Runnungitms which can attack the Snits
column1460:
plus Makums which can add more Runnungitms or replace lost Snorgs.

The Snits want to find the Spark of Life hidden in one of the organs
column1461:
but some organs hid explosive Splops instead.

Originally published in The Dragon Magazine #11. TSR published three boxed versions of the game which made some changes from the magazine version
column1462:
primarily a change to the Bolotomus turn order.

A further revised version of the game was published in Snits!.


""
column1471: Before Elfenland there was Elfenroads.  Players attempt to travel from city to city on the map using the resources of cards
column1473:
and transportation chits. The player best able to juggle the three resources and visit the most cities by game's end wins.

Re-implemented by:

Elfenland

column1486: Blood Bowl is a game of Fantasy Football.  The basic game features a match between a human team and an orc team.  Ostensibly the teams are playing football.  In fact each team takes turns moving
column1487:
blocking and advancing the football down the field. The game comes with plastic miniatures.

This game is a part of the Blood Bowl Series

""
column1501:
Satirical game in which each player represents a "major world power" and attempts to gain global domination (or annihilation) through the strategic use of propaganda or nuclear weapons...

Integrates with:

Nuclear Proliferation
Nuclear Escalation
Weapons of Mass Destruction
India Rails (using Nuclear War Bonus Pack #2: Expansion to India Rails and Nuclear War)


The latest reprint of the game features new artwork on the cards and two new cards:

Mars Probe (Secret): Take 1 million people from the discard pile.
Advanced Recycling (Special): Pick one used carrier or warhead from the discard pile.
column1515: The game board represents a fantasy land.  Players chose a character from a list of semi-standard fantasy types: Barbarian
column1518: etc.  The objective of the game is to travel through the land encountering event cards and gathering strength along the way.  Hopefully players will eventually become powerful enough to travel to the center of the board
column1519: endure the trials there and take the Crown of Command for the victory.  There were also several expansions released for this game
column1520:
which add new character choices and new places to travel.

Part of the Talisman series of games and expansions published by Games Workshop Ltd..

The first edition differs from the second only in the box cover art and the cards
column1521: which were printed in black and white (same artwork as the second edition
column1522:
though). The first edition had no expansions.

Talisman Expansion Set

column1537: Escape From Colditz is a 1-vs-many semi-cooperative game where one player is the Security Officer of the German forces
column1538: and the others are Escape Officers for various nationalities or prisoners of war (POWs).  Escape Officers try to acquire the equipment they need for a successful escape (rope
column1541:
while the Security Officer tries to hinder them by putting them in solitary confinement and consficating their equipment.

Play lasts for a pre-determined length of time or number of rounds. If an Escape Officer can free a pre-determined number of POWs (usually 2) before then
column1542:
they win. Otherwise the Security Officer wins.

The game was co-designed by Major PR Reid
column1543:
a British soldier who was one of the few to actually successfully escape from Colditz during the Second World War.

""
column1553: Pizza Party is a quick and simple variation of Memory for children which becomes much more adult and exciting when money is wagered on the outcome. Each player gets a color coded pizza slice with six slots used to hold topping discs. There are six discs of four different toppings placed face down on the table along with two "switch" ones for each color. Players flip one over on their turn and add it to their slice if it matches the topping they already have. If a "switch" one is revealed
column1554:
the player trades his or her slice with the player of the corresponding color or with any player if his or her own color is revealed.

Ages 4 to 8

""
column1563: Galaxy: The Dark Ages is the much-awaited sequel to AH's Titan: the Arena.  Originally
column1564: this game was Knizia's Grand National Derby
column1565: but two successive changes in theme have added much chrome to the design.  The basic idea remains intact: there are eight alien races
column1566: and at the end the only three will remain; bet on the aliens you think will make it to the end.  Numbered cards
column1568: are played below the alien homeworld cards.  As soon as each alien has a ship card and there is a definitive loser
column1569: said loser alien race is removed and a new round starts.  Several of the alien powers differ from those of TtA.  This version of the game adds further detail by calling the betting chips "starbases"
column1570:
which may be targeted by opponents' ships to lower their value.

""
column1580: Players attempt to shepherd their chosen dinosaurs through an ever-changing environment. Each player attempts to alter the environment during every game round. Extinction looms for those who can not survive in the current environment. Even those that can survive the environment need to survive a round of combat from opposing player's dinosaurs.
column1588: Players compete with each other to start fast food corporations
column1591: and build nationwide chains of restaurants.  The winner is the first player to make a million dollars
column1592:
or be the only player left in the game if all other players go bankrupt.

From Wikipedia:
Initially
column1593: the game looks like Monopoly. There is a board
column1594: with spaces around the edges. Some of these spaces can be controlled. Each time you land on a space controlled by an opponent
column1595:
you pay them money.

The inside of the board is an abstracted map of the United States. There are no fixed "color groups;" rather
column1596: your controlled outer spaces ("Markets") are the major cities of the USA
column1597:
and you need to use the inner map to connect these markets.

Connected markets act like multiple colors in a color group. However
column1598:
the expansion in the middle map is far more strategic than random.

Where Monopoly is a game about trading property
column1599:
Fast Food Franchise is a game of controlling the inner map.

""
column1619: Oregon Trail recreates the journeys of the pioneers who traveled across the Western U.S. during the 1820's - 1860's.  To a certain extent it is a role-playing game
column1620: as players are cast into the role of Trail Boss
column1621: responsible for shepherding his party from their jumping-off point to their ultimate destination.  Trail Bosses measure success (in relation to the other players) by retaining the highest percentage of the starting wagons
column1622:
personnel and stock when they arrive at their final destination.

""
column1630: Each player has seven pawns on opposite sides of a board with 31 spaces joined hexagonally. One end of the board
column1631: perpendicular to the two starting pawn rows
column1632:
is a pit which players try to force their opponent's pieces into. A player can move any of his pawns provided they are adjacent to at least one other friendly pawn. A player's group can also drag away and control adjacent opposing pieces as long as the opposing piece is kept away from it's allies. Win by putting three of your opponent's pawns "over the edge" of the pit or by separating all opponent's pawns thus immobilizing them.

""
column1637: The Uncanny X-Men Alert Adventure Game
column1641: Each player starts with two of eighteen X-Men superheroes each with its own strength
column1643:
intelligence and cheater power. Three battle zones on the board are populated with cards that show either villains to fight or heroes to recruit. Special dice determine whether players give or take hits in each battle. The goal of the game is to build up your team of superheroes and use them to defeat villains for points to win. The game includes detailed plastic figures for each of the X-Men.

""
column1658: Players lay tiles to build Black Morn Manor
column1659: where an evil Master resides.  Most players take on the roles of Envoy
column1660: who need to discover the Master's identity
column1661: find the item to which he is vulnerable
column1662: and destroy the Master.  One player starts as a Minion
column1663:
who attempts to find the influence item and remove it from the grounds.

""
column1672:
Described by the Publisher/Designer:

Triple Threat Baseball! is a dice baseball board game designed for family play. Replicates the play-by-play action of a traditional baseball game. Is not a real player
column1673: stats-based game.  Includes two levels of play:  beginning and advanced.  Both levels feature the throwing of two batting dice which result in 15 standard batting outcomes and 6 situational play outcomes.  In addition
column1674: the advanced level utilizes 14 different strategy offensive and defensive play cards which are used at the descretion of both managers/players in order to influence the flow of the game.  Also in the in the advanced version

the fielding team manager interacts and intervenes using a single fielding die. Both versions include the use of a standard baseball scorecard record keeping method. Ultimate Soccer is a new and exciting soccer board game that allows you to be the player as well as the coach. You play against each other alternating as an attacker and a defender. For the shot on goal the attacker and the defender only roll one die a piece to simulate the shooter and the goalkeeper.

Fate cards are things that can happen during a game like red card

column1926:
Box description:
War of Resistance is a detailed
column1927: operational level game which chronicles the second Sino-Japanese Conflict starting on July 7
column1928: 1937. Often touted as the true beginning of World War II
column1929: this 8 year war is the culmination of a decade of aggressive Japanese policy in northern and central China. The game covers the conflict through Pearl Harbor on December 7
column1930:
1941.
The Chinese theatre is neither trivial nor inconsequential to the progress and outcome of World War II on a global scale. Over one million soldiers on each side perished. It is estimated that another 7.5 million Chinese civilians died. Over 40 million Chinese were left homeless. The vast majority of Japanese ground combat and support soldiers were engaged in China
column1931: preventing their use against the western Allies in the Pacific. America's material dominance may have been the decisive factor contributing to the Japanese demise
column1932:
but Japan was already doomed to failure in the Chinese quagmire. This is essential to the greater understanding of the war in the Pacific.
Western nations tend to ignore and forget the Chinese contribution to the war effort. It is an indication of western arrogance that World War II is considered to have started on September 1
column1934: 1937. The Chinese war effort was far from stellar
column1935:
but it was enormous. The immensity of the conflict sapped the Japanese war machine to exhaustion.
War of Resistance is a two-player game

column1937:
and the other the fractured Chinese military forces. The Japanese player must force the collapse of the Chinese national will to resist. The Chinese player must cling to survival until the entry of the western nations into the Pacific war ensures ultimate victory over the Japanese invaders. Both sides maneuver their forces and conduct combat in an attempt to achieve these goals.

One rules booklet.

Trax is a two player abstract strategy game of loops and lines. It can be played on any flat surface (no board). The square tiles have straights on one side and curves on the other.
The rules of TRAX are simple: place tiles adjacent to those already in play such that the colours of the tracks match. The objective is to get a loop or line of your colour while attempting to stop your opponent in their colour. What gives Trax its strategic depth is the forced play rule which allows (or even requires) multiple tiles to be played in a turn.

column2290:
from Game Cabinet Review:

2 - 5 players attempt to settle and govern a new land of six villages. Each player may only introduce two new villagers per turn across five or six turns total. Villagers start as farmers earning a fixed income. Part of that income may be spent to purchase trade licenses which allow your villagers to set up as traders. Traders earn an income based on the population of their village. Each village must also elect a representative to government each turn. These councilors move to town and have no income for that turn (so much for realism - there is no provision for special interest groups or political action committees!). The government must decide whether to tax the farmers
column2292: or revoke one type of trade license. When this session of government breaks up councilors can either pay their own way home or pay a small fee and remain in government for another turn (well

column2294:
the villagers and traders earn income and pay their taxes. The player that has the most money after the last round of play inherits control of the lands of Keywood and wins the game.

Keywood is Richard Breese's first game in the key series.

column2477:
Described by the Publisher/Designer:

M K Morrison developed Big Battle over a number of years. He fine tuned it by play testing against an international chess master in New Zealand. Big Battle is a chess variant played on a 10 by 10 chess board. It has two new pieces called Princes which combine the powers of the chess knight and the Big Battle Queen. The Big Battle queen in addition to the powers of the ordinary chess queen can also jump over an immediately adjacent piece. The pawns (called soldiers in Big Battle) can move one two or threes squares; not just on their first moves but for any move. It makes for a pretty sharp end game. Almost all the pieces in Big Battle have enhanced powers when compared to their chess counterparts. There have been a number of Big Battle tournaments in New Zealand
column2478:
including two national tournaments. You can find out more about Big Battle at the Chess Variants page or at Zillions of games. They have a script for playing Big Battle.

column2487:
FROM THE BOX: One of these headlines appeared in an actual tabloid newspaper. the other three were made up by a group of friends playing Tabloid Teasers. Which one is the real one?

In Tabloid Teasers the fun begins when you are given part of a headline that appeared in one of the national tabloids. Then all players fill in the blank to create a wild and outrageous headline of their own. Now all the headlines - including the real one - are read out loud and players vote for the one they think is real. If you're right. You move ahead. You also advance when you fool another player into thinking your incredible headline is the real one!
If you're ready for an hysterical time of absurdity and fun - you're ready for Tabloid Teasers!

column2626:
Focus (or Domination) is a Sid Sackson abstract strategy game in which players attempt to make moves and capture pieces in such a manner that their opponent(s) have no moves remaining.

On a turn a player may move a piece or stack of pieces based on the number of pieces that comprise it as well as the number of pieces to be moved (e.g. 1-piece = 1 space
column2627: 3 piece stack = 3 spaces.)  When a stack grows over five pieces
column2628:
pieces from the bottom of the stack are removed to bring the stack back down to five. Pieces of a player's own color that are taken by that player are reserved to re-enter the game at a later time; pieces of the opponent's color are kept as captured. Reserved pieces can be entered on a turn in any space on the board in place of making a move of pieces; strategic use of reserved pieces can make the game by utilizing them to capture stacks controlled by opponent(s).

Sackson includes the game In his 1969 book
column2629: A Gamut of Games.  The book  makes a reference to the Whitman Publishing  Company production of 1965
column2630:
along with reporting that the two-handed version was first described in the October 1963 issue of Scientific American Magazine.

column2649:
from a session report:

In essence it’s a round-and-round trick game
column2650:
combining Frank’s Zoo with Hattrick. 4 suits valued 1-10. High beats low. Net (or joker) beats 10. A 1 (or joker) beats Net. And then we’re back into the numbers and round we go again. The trick is won when everyone passes.

7’s
column2651: 8’s and 9’s each have a sex. When one is played
column2652: if a player can play the same rank but of an opposite sex
column2653: a second trick is formed a la Hattrick. It’s a powerful play
column2654: because the round then ends the moment either trick gets back to whoever played a currently winning card
column2655:
improving the odds of you winning a trick. And causing all sorts of calculations as to what the best play is.

Winning a trick with a net
column2656: or someone playing their last card induces a new deal. If you have a crappy hand
column2658: concede and get a new hand. Otherwise
column2659:
kick-start it again with a 1.

In the round that someone wins their tenth trick (you start with 1
column2660: so it’s actually the ninth trick)
column2661:
the last player to win their tenth trick in that same round wins.

column2669: Megiddo is played on a round board consisting of six rings connected by six spokes. Each player in turn places a stone on one of the intersections in an attempt to get six pieces in a row in one of several configurations. A row of six could be either along a spoke
column2672:
in a spiral from innermost to outermost rings. A win could also be achieved by capturing enough pairs of opposing pieces by bracketing them on either side.
Megiddo won the "Best new game" at the International Toy and Hobby Fair held at Olympia
column2673:
London 1986


MEGIDDO GAME REDESIGNED FOR A NEW GENERATIONThis challenging game of strategy was first developed by Steve Baldwin in the mid-1980's. It became very popular with players around the world.

In 2011
column2674: Steve’s son Josh decided to re-release Megiddo with an updated design and new innovative rule change. Klündt | Hosmer re-designed the look of the game for a new generation of players. A redesigned board

column2676:
named after an ancient Hebrew city where numerous historical battles were waged.

Megiddo will be available for purchase on Amazon.com and will soon be available as an app for iPhone and Android smart phones.

We love design. And sometimes it really does feel like a game.

From Klundt Hosmer website

column2687: Last Chance is contract Yahtzee with side betting. Each player starts with a stake of chips. One of seven cards is overturned which shows a combination a player must roll on five dice. The tougher the combo
column2688: the more the cards are worth if won. Players bid on the chance to roll for the card. Those who don't win the bid can bet for or against the roller. If the roller makes the combo
column2689: he gets his bid back plus the card's stated value plus any bets made against him. If he fails
column2690: he loses his bid money. Any dice he applied to the combo stay on the card and players bid again on the partially completed card. If a player is low on cash
column2691: he can call "last chance" during bidding to win the bid automatically. Failure to make the combo will cost that bidder the game
column2692:

column3033: collecting up impossible artifacts and priceless works of art (at the moment just before history records their destruction)
column3034: coming to grips with the paradoxes of time travel
column3036:
changing pivotal events and altering the course of history itself. How would the timeline be different if Lincoln and JFK had not been assassinated? And is that the version of reality that you came from originally...the one you must return to in order to win? It's all packed into a fast and easy Fluxx-style card game that will take you to the beginning of time and back again.

""
column3051: 2038 is a space mining adaptation of the 18xx series of games.  First
column3052:
you have the ever important stock trading rounds followed by operating rounds where you try to deliver commodities mined from the asteroid belt.

Instead of laying track
column3053: the players explore the asteroid belt and lay claims to various mining resources. During operation rounds
column3054: ships move from mine to mine limited only by their fuel and the players' refueling stations. Operation is thus more flexible than in most 18xx games
column3055:
and the randomly generated map greatly increases replay value.

""
column3065:
from Game Cabinet Review

Each player is a doctor practicing a specific type of medicine - acupuncture
column3068: electric shocks - all the very latest techniques
column3069: all neatly color coded. Your hand of numbered cards may have some of your own color
column3070: and certainly some of other players' colors
column3071: and both low and high cards are useful as we shall see. In the manner of Carry On Doctor
column3072: the hapless victim patient is wheeled in before the arrayed quacks. Every patient is different
column3073: but your aim is to cure him (by having the largest combined total of cards in your color) without killing him (ditto
column3074: but exceeding the patient's specified limit). Your typical private patient is pretty weedy
column3075: so expires on a total higher than 14. You might play your own 8 card hoping to get close to the total
column3076:
but your rivals will be only too pleased to play a 5 and a 3 to kill him off. The body goes into your mortuary (minus points) hopefully to be offset by cured patients (positive points). And that is it.

""
column3084: Axiom is a two player strategy game that is played in three dimensions.  The board is made up of twelve cubes
column3085: six of each color. Each player has two pawns which snap into the indentations on the cubes.  The object is to capture one of the other player's pawns.  On a turn
column3086: a player can move one of their pawns over the surfaces of the cubes
column3087:
or move one of their cubes to change the playing surface.

At Essen 2008
column3088: a new version was released with a new physical design: smooth curved pawns
column3089:
held into the indentations by magnets.

""
column3097: A unique blend of elements from Chess and Checkers
column3098: an abstract game for two players using the pieces: Defenders
column3101: and Warriors.  While Warriors can move in any direction (like the Queen in Chess)
column3102: Sabers may only move cardinally (as rooks) and Tridents may only move diagonally (as bishops).  Defenders
column3104: cannot capture but are used to block or confound one's opponent.  Pieces are captured in a Checkers-like fashion of being jumped over
column3105: with special rules for corner captures
column3106:
and piece substitution. An unusual game combining very well-known mechanics from two of the classics.

""
column3119: Carcassonne is a tile-placement game in which the players draw and place a tile with a piece of southern French landscape on it. The tile might feature a city
column3123: and it must be placed adjacent to tiles that have already been played
column3124: in such a way that cities are connected to cities
column3127: the player can then decide to place one of their meeples on one of the areas on it: on the city as a knight
column3128: on the road as a robber
column3129: on a cloister as a monk
column3130: or on the grass as a farmer. When that area is complete
column3131:
that meeple scores points for its owner.

During a game of Carcassonne
column3132: players are faced with decisions like: "Is it really worth putting my last meeple there?" or "Should I use this tile to expand my city
column3133: or should I place it near my opponent instead
column3134: giving him a hard time to complete their project and score points?" Since players place only one tile and have the option to place one meeple on it
column3135:
turns proceed quickly even if it is a game full of options and possibilities.

First game in the Carcassonne series.

""
column3150: The Lord of the Rings is a co-operative game in which the object is to destroy the Ring while surviving the corrupting influence of Sauron. Each player plays one of the Hobbits in the fellowship
column3151:
each of which has a unique power.

Over the course of the game
column3152: you make your way across four conflict game boards
column3153: representing some of the most memorable conflicts from the entire trilogy: Moria
column3156: and Mordor. Each conflict board tests your small Fellowship to the utmost as you must play your quest cards to advance along multiple tracks. These tracks represent fighting
column3160: and by playing quest cards from your hand with matching symbols
column3161:
you can keep moving forward and push closer to victory.

The master game board indicates both the physical progress of the fellowship across Middle Earth and the corrupting influence of Sauron on the hobbits. If you're able to slip past your foes
column3162: you can hope to escape with minimal corruption
column3163: healing your hurts at safe havens along your path
column3164: such as the forest kingdom of Lothlórien. By playing your cards right and advancing quickly
column3166: unlock legendary cards to aid your journey
column3167: or find life tokens to help stave off corruption — not to mention advancing quickly through the conflicts. As you travel
column3168: the One Ring can be a crucial tool in your journey
column3169: allowing you to hide from sight
column3170:
but repeated use will draw the attention of Sauron and corrupt the heart of the Ring-bearer.

Your journey leads you deeper into the darkness with each passing conflict
column3171: and safe havens become few and far between. You must carefully watch the corruption track because if the Sauron miniature ever meets a Hobbit
column3172: that player is eliminated — and if the Ring-bearer is eliminated
column3173: all players lose as Sauron reclaims the power of the One Ring. To win
column3174:
throw the One Ring into the volcanic fires of Mount Doom.

This game should not be confused with Reiner Knizia's children's game (Lord of the Rings) with the same title
column3175:
or with his very different two-player Lord of the Rings: The Confrontation.

Lord of the Rings - Limited Edition

A special edition limited to 500 copies in the English language and 250 in German published by Sophisticated Games and Kosmos in November 2001. The Limited Edition has a silver 22 carat gold plated ring
column3177:
and a signed and numbered John Howe print. Box signed by Reiner Knizia.

""
column3185: Hijara ... 2-player abstract strategy board game of concentration – using placement of small stones
column3186:
strategy and points accumulation.

Game play: start with an empty board
column3187:
end with a full board and the player who accrues the most points is the winner.

The three ways to score points:
4 numbers of a kind in a row - horizontally
column3189:
diagonally scores 10 points.
4 numbers in sequence in a row - horizontally
column3191:
diagonally scores 15 points.
4 numbers in a square scores 20 points.

Two additional optional ways to score points:
4 numbers of a kind in the 4 corner squares scores 10 points.
4 numbers in sequence in the 4 corner squares scores 15 points.

You snooze
column3192:
you lose - as overlooked points are forfeited.

A singular game for two with only one rule - i.e. numbered squares may be filled in any order however
column3193:
stones must be placed on the square [being filled] in numerical sequence of that square.
