column3204: Screaming Eagles is a jet fighter dogfight with a unique board that allows for some bizarre moves. Players control 1 or 2 fighters and try to shoot each other out of the sky. Movement direction is determined by card play
column3205: and movement distance is determined by die roll. When your fighter moves off the front edge of the board
column3206: it "loops" to the back of the board and continues. If you successfully position your jet behind an enemy
column3207: open fire with you cannon or a missile.  Damage is assessed by a die roll
column3208:
and multiple hits are needed to bring down a plane unless a(n un)lucky shot strikes the cockpit or fuel tank. This is simple game that plays at jet speed!

""
column3223: Cartagena takes as its theme the famous 1672 pirate-led jailbreak from the fortress of Cartagena. Each player has a group of six pirates
column3224: and you want to be the first to have all six escape through the tortuous underground passage that connects the fortress to the port
column3225:
where a sloop is waiting for them.

To move a pirate
column3226: you need to play a card from your hand. Each card bears one of six symbols (dagger
column3229: and when you play a card
column3230: you move one of your pirates forward to the next matching symbol in the tunnel
column3231: leapfrogging over matching symbols where another pirate already stands. The only way to get more cards
column3233: is to move backwards; more specifically
column3234: you move one of your pirates backwards to the first space that holds one or two pirates
column3235: drawing one or two cards after doing so. Each turn
column3237:
whether moving forward or backward or both.

When you move a pirate to the end of the track
column3238: it jumps on the sloop where it must await the other pirates in its crew. With every step toward victory
column3240: you have fewer and fewer pirates to move each turn
column3241: possibly locking you in to actions you don't want
column3242:
so be sure to plan ahead and not leave yourself empty-handed!

""
column3252: Attila's mounted Huns overran Europe causing the Germanic tribes in their path to flee and penetrate the outer provinces of the declining Roman empire. In Attila
column3253:
the players influence the migrations of the Germanic tribes to the Roman empire. The winner is the player who has exerted the best influence on the most successful of the tribes.

Players have a hand of cards which correspond to the invading tribes. A turn consists firstly of playing a card and placing the matching tribal marker onto an area of the board
column3255: then secondly either repeating this or increasing their influence in that tribe. If a province now contains 5 tribal markers in total
column3256: war breaks out between the tribes. The basic strength of each tribe is the number of markers there
column3257: but each player can add matching cards from their hand to boost this. The weakest tribe is eliminated (or rather
column3258: all tribes with the lowest total)
column3259: leaving the province at peace and with no possibility of further tribal markers being added. Scoring occurs four times during the game at the end of each century; the first century ends after one war
column3260: the second after a further two and so on. The player with the most influence in each tribe scores 1 point for each tribe marker
column3261: the player in second place scores one point per area the tribe is in (thus if there is only one tribal marker of one sort in each area both 1st and 2nd will score the same). The influence a player gains increases in each century
column3262:
so large swings in control are possible.

Players are thus aiming to expand tribes in which they have the most influence (and conversely
column3263: are gaining influence in the tribes they expand) whilst at the same time trying to manipulate the timing and provinces where wars happen with a view to protecting their own favoured tribes and eliminating others. Gameplay is therefore not just about playing out as many of 'your' tribes as you can as you will need matching cards to defend with
column3264: and in any case may simply not have the right cards in hand. And sometimes you will want to provoke a conflict
column3265:
for example by adding a tribe you don't have much influence in to finish an area where one of your favoured tribes is strong.

""
column3278:
This is Avalon Hill's game of Fantasy Adventure.

This game uses hexagonal modular map sections
column3279:
providing a different board layout for each game.

Map tile-sections are placed on a blank mapboard to make up the arrangement of the Enchanted Islands for that game.

Most of the game consists of performing various mini-quests by moving around the 18 islands to pick up marker counters for the specific quest.

Each quest adds to the 10 quest per fortnight (14 days) requirement. Failure to reach this total of quests among all players causes one of the 18 islands to be flipped over and taken out of the game.

In this way the players are competing mainly versus the game system.

Endgame consists of players racing against each other to be first to collect 6 Gem Fragments and take them to the High Druid.

column3291: Players race to get a set number of "Superstar Points"
column3292: through paid gigs and hit singles
column3293: using the familiar "draw-one play-one" method. You build your band using member cards
column3294: and equip them with instrument cards and reputation cards. When a "gig" card comes up
column3296: then add in the bonuses from their band members
column3297: the highest roller getting the gig. "Contract" cards allow you to start playing "Hit Singles" on yourself (for more "Superstar Points")
column3298:
and other cards affect your band and gameplay in various different ways.

""
column3307:
Described by the Publisher/Designer:

We all love to share stories with our friends and family
column3308:
it's a favorite pastime across many generations. But haven't you ever wondered if some of the stories you hear are FIBS . . . or NOT?

This notion is just what makes FIB-OR-NOT? so fun to play.

FIB-OR-NOT? is the outrageously funny game of telling stories. Whether the stories are FIBS . . . or NOT
column3309:
is all up to you. There are no right or wrong answers and there is no questioning your knowledge of trivial facts.

How to Play:
Players select subject cards and take turns telling stories.

Story Teller - The objective of the game is to fool the other players. Either your real story is so outrageous that it sounds like a fib
column3310:
or your fib is so believable that it sounds real. Move forward one space for every player you fool.

Listener - The objective is to properly guess if the story is a FIB . . . or NOT. Guess correctly
column3311:
and you move forward one space.

The first person to reach the FINISH square is the winner.

The game is easy to play
column3312:
it's entertaining and it's educational.

FIB-OR-NOT? makes a great Party Game and a fantastic Family Game too.

Have fun
column3324: Players are the heads of 1 of 6 fictitious music companies
column3325: trying to predict/influence the popularity of 14 different musical acts. Each turn
column3326: players get 7 chits with +/- values on them
column3327: 5 of which they may use to secretly vote for the bands they want to support. Players are awarded points at the end of a round if one of their bands is in the top 6 slots. Players also have 2 special chits that either award extra points if played on a band that jumps to #1
column3328: or add/deduct points based on how far up (or down) a band moves from its original position. Some bands in the last 4 slots are removed at the end of a round depending on their original board position
column3329:
and the top 3 are removed (one-hit wonders) once a player's score reaches the 30 and 50 point mark. The game ends once a player reaches 70 points total. Very nice artwork and goofy band names (as only the Germans can do it) are complemented by one of the cooler game components ever; a wooden "CD Player" that the DJ (dealer) uses to tally up the votes.

Please be aware that
column3330: although this was formerly listed as a family game
column3331:
a few of the band names contain adult language.

Online Play


BrettspielWelt (real-time)

For the People is a grand strategy game of the American Civil War covering the conflict from Texas to Pennsylvania
column3346: from the firing on Fort Sumter to the end at Appomattox Court House. You take the role of either President Lincoln or President Davis and command the armies
column3350:
and even battle incompetency and political intrigue among members of your own cabinet.

For the People includes a deck of strategy cards for conducting campaigns and incorporating the many events and personalities of the war. The Confederate player can build ironclads
column3354: and work towards foreign intervention. The Union player can build up his naval blockade
column3358:
and issue the Emancipation Proclamation. Relive the history of this exciting time when our nation was torn asunder.

TIME SCALE: 4 months per turn
MAP SCALE: Point-to-point system
UNIT SCALE: 6
column3359:
000 men per strength point
NUMBER OF PLAYERS: One or two

COMPONENTS
420 full-color
column3360:
die-cut counters

130 Cards [101 Kb pdf]

DESIGNER: Mark Herman

MAP & CARD ART: Mark Simonitch
COUNTER ART: Mark Simonitch & Rodger B. MacGowan


(BGG description:)

This is the 4th entry in the We the People system of games

column3365:
this is nontheless more of a serious hobby game than any of the previous entries in the genre.


(Note from Mark Herman:)

The game was reprinted and the latest and final version of the rules has incorporated all of the previous FAQs plus has re-written some of the more troublesome rules sections (rivers). To date
column3366: after a grueling three-year on-line tournament
column3367: no rules questions of note have been forthcoming. The above write up is mistaken when it states that "For The People" is based on "Hannibal v Rome"
column3368:
but was my second game in the "We The People" genre that I created. The game dropped my battle card system in lieu of a more traditional combat results table to speed play and increase historical accuracy.

UPDATE:
The 2006 edition

the only difference between this and the 2006 edition is I added some variant rules to the rulebook. This rulebook is available from GMT games as a free download.

column3384:
with each card listing an historical event and the year in which it occurred.

At the start of the game
column3386: which are then placed face up in chronological order. On their turn

Someone once said: "The General Election is like a game. To win

Your objective is to win enough votes to get a majority of the 635 seats in Parliament. And if you have to make a few hollow promises . . . well that's politics. This game is about as realistic as it's possible to be

column3437: Corsairs is essentially a card game where players attempt to assemble the correct combination of provisions in order to be able to board galleys
column3438: whilst possessing a strong enough crew in order to board the ship and fend off their opponents potential counterattacks. The game comes with 30 galleys tiles in five different colors. Four of these galleys are placed face-up on the table and are ripe for the taking. Each galley indicates the combination of provisions which must be played before a player can attempt to board it. In addition
column3439: each galley indicates the victory points it is worth
column3441:
which must be met or exceeded for it to fall prey to the pirates.

Players are each dealt an initial hand of six cards
column3442: most of which depict one of six different types of provisions (water
column3447:
several cards depict corsairs (pirates) with values ranging from 2 - 4.

On their turn
column3448:
players must play 3 cards. They may play them:

a) beside a galley to begin amassing provision cards so as to eventually match the provision requirements indicated on the galley.
b) to the discard pile
column3449:
replacing them with cards chosen from rummaging through the discard pile
c) 'fire a broadside' by playing any card to the discard pile and rolling dice. He may then steal matching provisions placed by the galley by other players.

Once a player assembles all of the necessary provisions
column3450: he can attempt to board the ship. He needs to have enough corsairs
column3451: to add to the roll of two dice to beat the boarding value of the galley. Other players may also attempt to board the galley at the same time
column3452:
and the one with the highest boarding value wins it. The others lose all the cards played next to the galley. A new galley is then made available.

The winner is the player with most VP from galleys boarded.

(precis from the review by gschloesser)

column3467: and in each gambling joint where a gambler has been played

but doing well in the negotiation can make the difference between coming in first or second.

column3545:
players must race to finger the right items on the table — but winning an item isn't good enough as you need to protect it from being stolen while still hunting for more.

In more detail
column3546: you set up the game by placing all of the multi-colored and strangely shaped cardboard bits on the table. Each round
column3547: one player is the director and takes charge of flipping over a card that depicts one or more of these bits. Everyone races to place a finger on the depicted items first

any opponent who touches it first will steal it away.

If a player has seven or eight bits in front of them

Golf Masters is part of the line of physical dexterity games published by Goldsieber published under the DSF imprint (see also: Tennis Masters).

The game is played like real golf over a series of 18 holes with a target number for par. Each hole is constructed from some combination of the six modular boards or a subset thereof. A recommended tournament course is provided. There are special rules for each of the course hazards

and ponds.

The game is scored like real golf.

column3586: 2-4 players feed the pigs... trying not to cause them to have Fette Bauche (full bellies). Unfortunately

column3600: ...und Tschüss! means "So Long!" and is a simple card game where players compete for successive scoring cards on the table by laying cards with the lowest total. The trick is
column3601: there is one scoring card fewer than the number of players
column3602:
so someone always goes empty handed. A bit like musical chairs.

The deck has blue cards numbered 1 to 15 and red cards numbered -5 and -10. According to the number of players
column3603: you're dealt a hand and then the scoring cards are laid out. So with 6 players
column3604: you get 9 cards and compete for 5 on the table. The scoring cards are sorted from lowest to highest and everybody chooses a card from their hand and shows it. The lowest value card wins the lowest scoring card (which could easily be a negative!). That player is out and the remaining players choose another card. Whoever has the lowest total takes the next lowest scoring card and is out
column3606: until there are 2 players left competing for the final scoring card. Again
column3607: you add a card to your total
column3608: and whoever now has the HIGHEST total wins the last scoring card. Which means that if you can't go for the prize
column3609:
you try to duck out earlier. Get it wrong and you've no chance of getting points. Play twice through the deck and the highest points scored wins.

Part of the Goldsieber à la Carte line of games.

Illuminati is a classic Steve Jackson (I) game of world domination. Each player takes on the role of a secret society attempting to spread its tendrils into special interest groups throughout the world.

The game consists of three different cards (illuminati cards
column3700: and special event cards) and money. During a player's turn
column3701: a new card is drawn from a deck containing both group cards and special event cards. If it is a special event
column3702: the player in turn keeps the card and plays it when desired. If it is a group card
column3703: it is turned up along with any other face-up cards. The player in turn may then attempt to take over any group. This can be either a group on the table or a group already controlled by another player. If another player already controls the group it is more difficult to take it over
column3704:
but not impossible.

How difficult it is to take over a group depends on the strength of the controlling group
column3705: the resistance of the group being taken over
column3706: the proximity of the group being taken over to the controlling player's illuminati card (if someone already controls it)
column3707: and other factors. Once this is determined
column3708: both the attacking and defending player can modify the odds further by spending "megabucks". Once a group is taken over
column3709: it has to be attached to the card structure the player already controls. How cards can be attached to each other is limited by in- and outbound arrows on the cards
column3710:
and maintaining a well-structured tree of groups can be vital to success.

The winning condition for each player is different and depends on what illuminati card that player has.

This first edition contains 54 small black and white cards.

column3930:
A challenging mind testing game.

1 board
2 cubes
1 hourglass
6 game figures
6 game stones
8 event cards
36 task cards

The game consists of playing pieces that you can move around freely and with which it is possible to construct a square or a rectangle or a triangle or other geometric shapes. A timer is used to determine how much time one has to construct the required shape. Once you complete the required shape you turn the timer on its side. Others then have the remaining time to solve the puzzle or can work as a group to solve and get the points for solving.

Shuffle the 36 task cards and 8 event cards together and placed them in the unsolved tasks area. Each player takes a set of stones/playing pieces. Players place their marker on the beginning of the scoring track. Beginners can play a shorter game by using the 24 joker cards
column3932:
and starting on the “short game” scoring track location. The scoring track consists of 8 circles and then the center winning area. Each time you complete a task in the required time you can move your scoring marker one circle closer to the center square and victory.

Event cards give special privileges. One gives the solver two turns through the hour glass to solve the puzzle another allows the solver to move two spaces ahead if they solve the puzzle.

You may distract another player from solving the puzzle.

1 – 6
1 hour

column3980: Goldsieber attempts to capture the feel of tennis in this oddball dexterity game.  Each player has a  still tennis player figure which is used to volley the ball back and forth across the net.  Under each player
column3981: and under the translucent surface of the board is the movement paddle for that player
column3982: which dictates how far the playing figure could move for the subsequent turn.  The game field is set up just like a tennis court
column3983: with the requisite lines and a net
column3984: and the players volley a soft tufted "tennis ball".  One player serves the ball
column3985: and if it lands within the fair territory
column3986: the receiving player checks to see if it fell within their movement paddle space.  That player then moves the center of their paddle under the ball and uses their figure to return the ball
column3987: and so on until one player scores by their opponent knocking the ball out of play
column3988: or by playing the ball in a space where their opponent cannot reach it within their movement zone.  All of the ball volleying is performed by tensing back the racket of the playing figure
column3989:
and then releasing it to launch the ball across the net. Scoring is handled just like regular tennis scoring.

column4069: players are looking to drive cattle across the west
column4070: establishing towns.  If you don't like the way something is going
column4071: you can fight other players for control with your cowboys.  You can rob the bank
column4073:
and shoot those pesky farmers!

Gameplay: To Start each player receives a set of colored player counters
column4075:
and two black action tokens and either $20 or $25 depending on number of players. The dice are rolled to determine the start player. Each player in turn order will place one of their cowboy counters in a town box of any of the 5 towns on the map until each player has placed 3 cowboys.

Each turn the players will bid for turn order
column4076:
take actions and move the turn marker one space. To bid for turn order each player places an amount of money under their turn order token in current player order. Players may either raise or drop out. If a player drops out all money bid so far is paid to the bank and their turn order token is placed in the furthest available spot from start player space on the turn order track. This continues until one player remains and becomes the start player for the round.

During the action phase each player will take 1 action in turn order. After everyone has taken a turn they repeat the procedure. The actions available are limited in number so turn order is important in doing what a player wishes to do. Actions available are: Buy Cattle in a town containing their cowboy(s)
column4079: Move Cattle from one town to another
column4080: Purchase Buildings or Transport counters in a town
column4081: Take a Farmer(reduces income and victory points from Cattle in the town they are placed)
column4082:
or Gunfight.

There are six different building and transport counters: StageCoach (these earn $1 per cowboy when cowboys are placed in or moved from the town containing the player's StageCoach)
column4083: Train (this doubles the income gained from all players Cattle in the same town and doubles victory points gained from Cattle at game end)
column4084: Bank (earns its owner $2 for each building or transport counter in the same town)
column4085: Store (earns the owner $1 for each Cattle counter belonging to other players in the town and $2 per Farmer counter in town)
column4086: Hotel (earns $1 for each cowboy belonging to other players in same town)
column4087: Jail (the sheriff in the Jail acts as an extra cowboy controlled by owner that can be added to Gunfights). Cattle and Farmers also earn money for players during an income round.  Each Cattle counter earns its owner $2 UNLESS the town also contains a Farmer (it only earns $1 if this is the case).  Oh
column4088:
the Farmer and Cowmen can't be friends.

Gunfights can be started to take over another players Building or Tranport counter
column4090: rob a Bank or remove a Farmer or Jail.  The player choosing the Gunfight selects the target of the attack.  All Cowboys belonging to each player in the town will be involved.  The remaining player's Cowboys in the town are not involved. However; the owner of the Jail can choose to help themselves
column4092: or they can add the Sheriff to the defender if wished.  Farmers that are attacked defend as a single cowboy.  Banks and Trains both have an intrinsic 1 Cowboy defense in addition to those in town of owner's color.  The player with the fewest Cowboys fires first and immediately removes casualties.  Each 5 or 6 rolled kills a Cowboy.  If the number of Cowboys is tied then firing is simultaneous.  A player may retreat instead of firing by moving each cowboy involved to a different town (only 1 per town) and loses the engagement.  If the attacker wins they take control of the target of the attack and may replace the counter (up to 2 counters if rustling Cattle) with one of their color (except for Banks
column4093:
Farmers and Jails). A Jail or Farmer is removed from play and a Bank is robbed. The successful robber rolls 3 die 6 and takes that amount of money from the owner of the Bank (the Bank remains under owner's control). If the owner of the Bank cannot pay the full amount (then pays all they have to the robber and the Bank is removed). Each time a player wins a Gunfight they take a Wanted Counter. If none remain they take it from another player their of choice.

Victory: After taking turns 3
column4095: 9 and 12 income is paid to players as delineated above.  The game ends after round 12.  Victory points are awarded for each Building or Transport counter (1 point per size of town).  So a building in a Town with 4 Building or Transport Counters including itself is worth 4 points to the owning player.  Each Cattle Counter is worth one victory point for the owner.  If a train is in the town each Cattle Counter is worth 2 points.  If a Farmer is in the town Cattle are worth 1 victory point less.  To illustrate
column4096: if a Farmer is in same town Cattle counters are worthless unless a Train is also present in the town.  In this case
column4097:
they would be worth 1 point each. The player with the most Building/Transport counters and Cattle in a town is considered to control the town and scores bonus points equal to the size of the town (Cattle do not affect town size but do affect control). The Player with most money gains 5 victory points (2 each in case of a tie). The Player with the most Wanted counters scores 4 victory points. The player with most Points wins.

The auction is a basic rising offer with passing until one winning bid remains. Players pay into the pot with contracts (in Nightmare Productions edition: money)

column4428:
What happens when the hunter becomes the hunted?

In Tally Ho!
column4429:
one player takes the role of the hunters and the lumberjacks; the other takes the role of the foxes and bears. Both players hunt each other!

At first the forest lies peacefully under the face-down tiles. As the players turn the tiles over and move them on the board
column4430:
the forest awakens and the hunt destroys the serenity of the forest. The lumberjacks cut swaths through the forest to provide hunting fields for the hunters. The bears then use these same aisles to track the hunters and lumberjacks. And both sides hunt the ducks who are just trying to live in peace!

The two sides are balanced with luck dominating the early game
column4431:
but skill taking over at the end. Good hunting!

Originally published by Spear Spiele in 1973 as Jag und Schlag

Kosmos republished the game in 2000 as Tally Ho! / Halali! as part of its Kosmos two-player series.

column4442: Players take turns laying down tiles of varying colors and sizes attempting to reach a secret goal in the painting (e.g. 4 contiguous red shapes). Before or after placing a tile players can slide pieces around to adjust the painting to their liking.
column4454:
This classic SPI game from 1980 covers the economic and political landscape of Medieval Europe from 771 to 1467 on an area map. Several scenarios allow players to do anything from a solitaire game during the Charlemagne's reign to the "Grand Scenario" that covers historical trends throughout the period.

Decision Games published a second edition in 2004
column4455: with a differently styled map.  It added optional expansion rules & counters for Armies
column4458:
along with additional Event Cards -- raising their number from 56 to 164.

At the start of each player's Round
column4459: Event Cards are drawn which change the strategic situation (such as Plague or Bounty) or benefit a player in various ways.  The descriptions of the Events contain a great deal of historical information
column4460:
adding much interest to the game.

Each player may attempt to perform up to five "Endeavors" per 25-year long Turn.

There are six types of Endeavors: Conquest
column4464: Fortification (including building Armies/Fleets) and Ruling. Additionally
column4465:
moving Armies/Fleets and Taxation may always be performed.

Endeavor resolution is diceless; instead "Year Cards" which show an array of results for each type of Endeavor are drawn. The card might also require a Leader Stature Check
column4466: which can change the player's Combat
column4468:
and Diplomacy ratings.

Endeavor resolution is affected by the appropriate Leader rating
column4472:
and Social State (which changes frequently). Poor performance can lead to Unrest or Rebellion in an Area.

An area's Social State value rises and falls as a result of Events and Endeavors
column4473:
and improving the Social State of your empire is an important object of play.

Optional rules add non-player Raiders and Magnates.

The Sword And The Stars is a galactic empire game based on the Empires Of The Middle Age game system.

column4485: Pacific Victory covers the war in the Pacific during World War II using the Columbia Block game system. Units are represented by wooden blocks which remain upright and hide the type and strength of the unit. A fusion of Columbia's older "Front" system and its newer "Victory" system

column4513:
The artifacts of an ancient space faring race wreak havoc on humanity and must be stopped! A solitaire game pitting the player against an automated platform of destruction. Take command of humanities finest squadrons of assault ships in a desperate attempt to destroy the ancient battle platform before your fleet is turned to space junk!

Crew-up your Paladin and set your jump vector for adventure! In this solitaire game an elite squadron of Paladin Class assault ships are under your command. Objective: Destroy an artifact battle platform while minimizing losses to your squadron. The automated platform will be firing deadly plasma bolts automatically and randomly. Avoid these while using your fusion guns to take out the platforms critical components before you are vaporized!

Mystery of the Abbey is a whodunit deduction game in the spirit of Clue. A monk has been murdered in a medieval French Abbey. Players maneuver their way through the Abbey examining clues and questioning each other to find out who is the culprit.

Monks are of three orders
column4533: bearded-clean shaven. One monk card is hidden
column4534: and the rest of the cards are distributed.  Turns consist of moving up to two spaces
column4535: and then asking a question of any other monks who are present there. (For instance
column4536: "how many fat monks do you have?".) Players may either take a "vow of silence" or answer truthfully; they then in turn get to ask the accuser a question.  "Mass" occurs every four turns: all players go back to the Sanctuary
column4538: and they then pass an ever growing number of cards to their left neighbor. Various rooms have special events or cards associated with them
column4539: e.g. in a Cell you get to pick a card from a neighbor
column4540: in the Cryptorum you get to pick up a card to take an extra turn later. Unlike Clue you don't automatically win by making a correct Accusation: you get 4 points for getting it right
column4541: but you also get 2 points for each correct Declaration of a single trait
column4542: and lose points for incorrect declarations and accusations. So
column4543: e.g. a person could correctly Declare the culprit but lose the game.  Unique Events cards add randomness to each play
column4544:
and the game begs for House rules to limit the questions.

column4588:
Simple card game of cycle racing. Players fight to hold the yellow jersey when the race ends.

Players are dealt 6 cards and draw a 7th before playing a pace card
column4589: and any additional modifiers. There are 84 pace cards numbered between 39 and 50
column4591:
Headwind (which subtract -2 from your pace) and Mountains (which ensure that no one can take the lead from the current player).

One player starts as the race leader with a yellow token
column4592: and plays a speed card. Successive players must match the leader's pace to stay in the Peleton (the race pack)
column4593: and each enjoys a +2 to their pace card simulating the benefit of decreased wind resistance.  If a player falls more than 2 behind the pack
column4594: than they draw chips (representing minutes) equal to the difference from their card and the race pace.  If a player starts his turn not in the Peleton
column4595:
than he does not get the +2 slipstream bonus.

If a player plays a card that is faster than the race leader
column4597: or make up time until they catch the Peleton.  If they take the lead
column4599:
and successive players must now match their tempo.

You must play Headwinds when you draw them
column4600: and you can use Spurts as you like.  You play Mountain cards on yourself or the race leader
column4601: and they prevent anyone from passing the leader
column4602:
and they also remove the 2 km slipstream bonus that other player otherwise enjoy.

The race ends when the deck runs out. The player holding the yellow token wins and scores a point
column4603:
the other players lose points equal to the chips in front of them.

Timing is everything if you plan to win.

Werewolf (also known as Mafia) takes place in a small town where a minority of the townsfolk hold a dangerous secret.

Each player is secretly assigned a role - Werewolf
column4626:
or Seer (a special Villager). There is also a Moderator who controls the flow of the game.

The game alternates between night and day phases. At night
column4627: the Werewolves secretly choose a Villager to kill. Also
column4628: the Seer (if still alive) asks whether another player is a Werewolf or not. During the day
column4629:
the Villager who was killed is revealed and is out of the game. The remaining Villagers then vote on the player they suspect is a Werewolf. That player reveals his/her role and is out of the game.

Werewolves win when there are an equal number of Villagers and Werewolves. Villagers win when they have killed all Werewolves. Werewolf is a social game that requires no equipment to play
column4630:
and can accommodate almost any large group of players.

column4645:
Adds several new aspects to Settlers of Catan but the two major ones are creating knights to protect the land from invading barbarians and building city improvements that confer benefits upon that city's owner. Adds tactical complexity to the game and game length.

Belongs to the Catan Series.

The game changes the base game in three main ways:

First
column4646: there are 3 new commodities in the game
column4650: which can be acquired from Forest
column4653: respectively. Cities that would normally produce two of one of those resources instead produce 1 resource and 1 of the corresponding commodity. (To make commodities easier to obtain
column4654:
each player starts the game with 1 city and 1 settlement on the board.) These commodities allow players to build city improvements that confer various advantages and eventually points.

Second
column4655: the deck of development cards is replaced by three different decks
column4656: each corresponding to one of the commodities. Building city improvements gives players a chance to draw these cards with every roll of the dice. Building more improvements will increase these chances
column4657: but cards cannot be bought directly in any way. These cards are similar to the development cards in the base game
column4658: but with a wider range of effects. (Some cards are balanced better as well - the new Resource Monopoly card
column4660:
can take no more than 2 of the named resource from any one player.)

Finally
column4661: players can also build knights on the island along their network of roads. These knights can be used to claim certain intersections and move the Robber (taking the place of Soldier cards)
column4662: but are also used to defend the island from periodic barbarian attacks. If the island is successfully defended
column4663: the player(s) with the most knights are rewarded. If not
column4664:
the player(s) with the fewest knights each have a city downgraded to a settlement.

column4681: or mining to their side.  A given planet may provide mineral resources and a number of settlement points -- the minerals can be collected for victory points

column4694: such as a heart) with six cards each
column4695: for a total of 60 cards. To begin
column4696: one card is removed from play and all the remaining cards dealt out (distribution may be uneven). Players now seek to collect full sets of six rumor cards and deduce which rumor set is missing a card. Players ask another about their hand
column4697:
e.g. "Do you have three hearts?" Players need only respond with an answer of "more" or "less" if the
number asked is incorrect
column4698: and play passes clockwise from the asking player. If the number asked is correct
column4699:
the questioner receives those cards and play passes to the
answering player. Sets of six rumors collected are placed on the table and score three points. At any point

scoring 10 points
for a correct guess and taking a penalty of 5 points for an incorrect guess.

column4711:
A light card game where players gain status by going out first.

The 80-card commercial deck contains cards ranked from 12 to 1
column4712: along with two Jesters. Each card bears a number
column4713: which is not only its rank
column4714: but also tells you how many of that card exist in the deck. In other words
column4717: four 4s and a single card ranked 1. The lower the number
column4718:
the better the rank.

The deck is dealt out to all players and the object is to get rid of your cards as fast as possible. The hand begins with one person playing one or more card to the center of the table. The cards played must all be of the same rank (although Jesters are wild
column4719: and may be played with any other cards). Each player in turn must now either play the same number of cards of a better rank
column4720: or pass. Play continues around the table until everyone has passed; at that point
column4721: the cards are cleared and whoever played the last set of cards leads the next round. After everyone has gone out
column4722: the players are ranked. For example
column4723:
the person who first got rid of all his cards becomes The Great Dalmuti. Players change seat position to represent the new hierarchy and begin another round. The Great Dalmuti is generally played for many rounds.

It is a commercial version of the traditional playing card game President (based on the Chinese game Zheng Shang Yu)
column4724:
which has also been reimagined as:


Dilbert: Corporate Shuffle
Pyramid Card
Scum: The Food Chain Game
Deathtrap Dungeon: Card Game

column4735: with the player who has the highest valued goblin or goblins in that lane winning 3 Ducats. There is also a penalty for finishing a race
column4737:
the person with the most Ducats wins.

From the back of the box:

Luck as well as strategy are important in this game. It starts out with the board filled with 36 coloured marbles in random distribution. Move by move players pick up marbles
column4746:
trying to collect colours. Colour sets score higher!

1. Each players has an arrow at the edge of the board
column4747:
which he moves.

2. The players take the marble which is at the intersection of the two arrows.

3. This is the table of points: the higher the number of marbles in one colour
column4748:
the higher the score!

4. The board is easily prepared for each new round.

Intersection

column4764:
Re-issue of Kramer's Niki Lauda's Formel 1 with tweaks.

Make as much money as possible
column4765: by becoming one of first at the finish line! If you place advanced RACE
column4766:
you can also make money by betting!

This game is based on running and betting;
Each player gets 200.000 credits and the deck of "Speed cards" is shuffled and divided among the players
column4767:
who now sort out the cards in the order they want.
Now the "Contestants cards" are stacked face down. Each card matches the colours of the player pawns (Red
column4771: Purple and White). Now there will be an auction of the cards
column4772:
where you figure our what to buy by the help of your "Speed cards". Each bidding starts with 10.000 credits and is raised by 10.000 credits. All players have to have at least one (1) "Contestant card".

The last player to buy a card starts
column4773: and plays a "Speed card" to move all the pawns as the card shows; a pawn can only be moved ahead; either straight or diagonally; never backwards or sideways. Only one pawn is allowed on a spot
column4774:
and it is NOT allowed to jump over another pawn.
An example of a Speed card could be:
Blue: 6 spaces
White 4 -
Black (means joker/free choice that is not on the card): 2 -
Yellow: 1 -
The speed cards also include "Sprints" and "Injury"

The player who's colour is first over the finish line gets 200.000 in price money. Second place pays out 150.000
column4775:
3rd 100.000 and so on.
Even if your colour have finished the race you continue playing your remaining speed cards.
The race ends when the fifth player have crossed the Finish line or when all "Speed cards" have been played.

The card dealing of both SC and CC plus the auction is now restarted and the next race goes on untill the agreed amount of races. The winner is the one with the most money.

Other games in Wolfgang Kramer's racing series include Detroit-Cleveland Grand Prix and Daytona 500.

""
column4797:
extrapolated from session report:

The theme of the game is based on the legendary necklace of Saba
column4798: which went to the grave with its owner upon her death. Sadly
column4799: dastardly grave robbers plundered the tomb and the valuable gems which comprised the necklace were scattered across the globe. Now
column4800: a wealthy sheik is anxious to reassemble the necklace and present it as a gift to his lovely bride. Players are charged with the task of assisting the sheik
column4801:
attempting to purchase the many gems at auction and then reassemble the necklace in the proper fashion.

The board depicts the frame of the necklace
column4802: with space for its 36 missing gems. In total
column4803: there are 44 gems in the deck
column4804: many of which will ultimately prove to be forgeries. Depending upon the number of players
column4805: each player receives from 3 - 7 gems to begin the game
column4807:
000. Four gems are revealed from the remainder of the deck and positioned into the frame.

The game is played in two major phases. During the first phase
column4808: players alternate placing a gem up for auction
column4809: ala Modern Art. The auctioneer receives the funds from the high bidder
column4810: who receives the gem. The winner has the option of keeping the gem
column4811: or placing it into the frame. If placed in the frame
column4813: 000 for other gems it touches and those radiating from it in straight lines
column4815: the reward is reduced to only $1
column4817: the auctioneer has the opportunity to purchase another gem from the deck for $2
column4818:
000.
Phase 1 ends when the gem deck expires. Phase 2 then begins with players reconstructing the necklace. In turn
column4819:
each player places a gem into the frame and earns funds as described above.

The twist in the game are the rules which must be followed in reconstructing the necklace. The main rules are:


The necklace must be symmetrical
column4820: with left and right halves containing the same jewels in the same places. All cards appear twice in the game
column4821:
so what appears on the left side must appear in the same position on the right side. The only exception to this is the center column. Any duplicate pieces are considered forgeries and are worthless.



Pieces of jewelry containing the same type of gem must be placed in uniform columns. Thus
column4822:
the first gem placed in a column dictates what kind of gem must appear in that same column.



The number of gems on a card can only be one greater than the number of gems on the cards directly above it.


Once the first gem is placed in a column
column4823:
it 'locks' that column AND the corresponding symmetrical column. Only gems which meet the above rules can subsequently be placed there.

The game ends once the necklace is completed. The player with the most money is victorious.

Each player has an identical set of 12 tiles displaying part of a network of computer cables. A further set is shuffled and placed face down in the centre of a 3x3 grid

Four markers are placed around the edge of the grid and these represent the only points at which the cabling can leave the grid. column4963:
using the same centre tile as displayed and connecting up the four “perimeter” markers. First one to complete a valid network wins the centre tile (1 VP). He then rearranges the perimeter markers if he wishes and turns over the next card to be played for.

column4995: each player has their own deck of forty cards
column4996: with cards 1-10 in four colors and a unique symbol on the back to identify which cards are theirs. At the start of each round
column4997: each player lays out 3-5 cards (depending on the number of players) face up in front of them to create their row; places a face-up stack of ten cards
column4999:
next to their row to create their Ligretto stack; and holds the remaining cards in hand face down.

Playing at the same time
column5000: each player tries to empty their Ligretto stack. If a player has a 1 card on top of any face-up stack
column5001: they play it to the center of the table. If they have a 2 card of the same color as any 1 in the center of the table
column5002:
they can place the 2 card on the 1. All cards in the central piles must be played in ascending order and must be the same color.

If a player can't play anything
column5003: they can reveal cards from the stack in their hand
column5004: counting them out in groups of three
column5005:
then laying them face up while revealing only the top card. They can play this top card onto a central pile as long as the rules for doing so are met.

As soon as a player empties their Ligretto stack
column5006: the round ends. Each player scores 1 point for each of their cards among the central piles
column5007: then loses 2 points for each card remaining in their Ligretto stack. In some versions of the game
column5008: the player with the highest score wins; in other versions
column5009: players then sort all the cards and play another round
column5010:
with the first player to reach 99 points winning.

A rules variant for Ligretto allows a player to play cards from their Ligretto stack or the cards in hand onto the cards in their row
column5011:
but only if the numbers are in descending order and the colors of adjacent cards are not identical.

column5043:
From the Designer/Publisher:

Like most games the main objective is to try and be the first to finish
column5044: you do this by traveling around the game board (using names as your fuel)
column5045: collecting one passenger from each of the following six categories
column5046:
then taking them to the main central station to complete the Nametrain™!

Music..
Any group or Musician as long as they are known as the recording artist

Television..
Any TV program
column5047:
but no using films shown on TV.

Film..
Any film whether it has been shown on the big screen
column5049:
male or female.

Actor/Actress..
Any actor or actress from TV
column5050:
stage or film

Well Known People..
A category for those that don't fall into any of the other categories.

Playing the game
To play Nametrain™ is very simple
column5051: somebody says a name from one of the six categories (listed above) and the last letter of that name is then used as the starting letter of the next. Each player then takes it in turn to roll the number dice and move their train along the allotted spaces
column5052:
they must then give an answer from the category they land on using the last letter from the previous players answer as the starting letter of their answer...and so on.

For example
The game is in full flow and it's your turn
column5053: the player to your right has left you on an 'E' by saying Bruce leE (they were on the actor/actress square). You roll the dice
column5054:
you move four spaces and land on the music square. You only have 60 seconds to say the name of a group or singer whose name begins with an 'E'.

Who do you say...the sands of time are slipping away...if you don't say a name soon you will lose one of your passengers
column5055: there's only a few seconds left...what about Elvis presleY. It gets you out of trouble and leaves the next player on a 'Y'
column5056:
they could now be the one in trouble with you taking one of their passengers.

and 2 players.

column5106: Twixt is a 2-player abstract game invented by Alex Randolph. TwixT is a "connection-type" game
column5107:
very similar to Hex. Other related games are Havannah and The Game of Y. "Connection type" means the object is to form a path connecting something to something else. This requires very different thinking from the standard battle-type game such as chess or checkers.

Some old US sets mention a 4-player variant
column5109:
but this probably wasn't Randolph's idea. The game was popular in the 60s and 70s as part of the 3M Bookshelf Series. Avalon Hill then acquired the series and issued the game themselves. Several European publishers have sold the game as well.

Twixt employs a pegboard
column5110: pegs and links.  The playing surface is a 24x24 square pegboard
column5112: with two opposite sides marked with one player's color and the other two sides marked with the other player's color.  Each player has a supply of pegs and links of their color.  50 of each piece type of each color
column5114: is an ample supply. Players alternate turns placing pegs and links
column5116:
in attempt to have a continuous path of links connecting the two sides of the board with their color.

After the 3M edition
column5117: Randolph added the pie rule. After the first peg is placed
column5118:
the opponent has the option to swap sides. This reduces the imbalance from the first move advantage.

On your turn you place one peg of your color on the board
column5119: and then add or rearrange your color links. Pegs may be placed in any vacant hole in the board except the corners and the last row on the sides of the opposing player. When two pegs of the same color are at opposite corners of a six hole rectangle (3x2 or 2x3)
column5120: a link may be placed between those two pegs.  Links may not be placed such that they cross other links.  Multiple links may be added on a single move. Usually
column5121: all links are to the peg just placed
column5122: but on your move you are allowed to remove as many of your own links as you wish
column5123:
and add your own links anywhere on the board as long as they are legal as described here.

When a player connects his two sides with a continuous path of links
column5124: he prevents his opponent from doing the same
column5126: and the player connecting his two sides wins the game. If neither side can complete such a path
column5138: From the designer Frank Branham: A 4 player partnership trick taking game themed around the Mexican Day of the Dead. (A particular favorite holiday of ours
column5139: as Sandi and I were married on that day in Marietta Confederate Cemetery.) It is short (about 30 minutes)
column5140:
and rather brain bending.

Dia De Los Muertos (Day Of The Dead) is played over three days as you send animals
column5142: then adults on to the afterlife. It is a basic trick taking game
column5143: except that most cards have an action with them. You play as a partnership
column5144: and if your side wins scoring cards (the dead or food)
column5145: you exchange a card with your opponent. Other cards allow swaps between partners
column5147:
cancelling other cards and so on.

The first time you play
column5148: there's a lot of checking the rules
column5150: remembering if you exchange cards. You spend more time figuring the game than playing the tricks. But after a couple of hands
column5151: it makes sense and you switch to game-playing mode. And here's where it pays. If you enjoy Bridge
column5152: you can figure out what your partner signals when they swap a card
column5153: or you can read the deck based on what's been played
column5154: you will really enjoy Dia De Los Muertos. If you don't like Bridge
column5155: or can't figure trick-taking games anyway
column5156:
steer well clear. It is rather brain-bending.

The original game has nice native graphics of the dead abroad and has a variant for 3 players. The re-issue as Four Dragons has an oriental theme.

Not to be confused with:

Dia de los Muertos (2007)

column5171: Football Strategy boils the sport down to play calling skill. The game's structure is simple: The defensive player selects one of 10 formation cards (ranging from an 8-man line "goal line stand" to a pass prevent defense with five safeties); the offensive player calls a play (a choice of 20
column5172: plus punting). Cross-indexing the choices on a matrix shows what happened. Except for "long gains"
column5173:
the outcome of each play against each defense is always the same. Dice are rolled only to determine the distance of long gains and the results of kickoffs and field goal attempts.

Each play consumes a prescribed number of seconds
column5174: from 15 to 45. The players mark off the time and play four quarters
column5175:
following the standard football rules.

For variety
column5181: the game is engrossing (see the "More Information" screen)
column5182: and play generally follows realistic patterns
column5183: though the handling of punts and on-side kicks (both more effective than in real life) is questionable. Also
column5184: because the design changed little after its debut in 1959
column5185: the plays and defenses don't reflect the state of the art in contemporary professional football. This is the era of Otto Graham
column5186:
not Eli Manning.

For those who are so inclined
column5187: Football Strategy lends itself to mathematical analysis. Many years ago
column5188: an entrant into the tournament at Origins went to the trouble of using game theory to generate charts showing the optimal mix of plays in different situations. He reached the finals but
column5189: in a victory for human intuition over number crunching
column5190:
lost the championship game by a touchdown and a field goal.

column5629: each player makes use of members of various tribes of the ancient world to build temples

The game plays out on a small game board representing regions of 5 ancient civilizations
column5636: and Assyrians.  Each player will be dealt a hand of cards (consisting of 5 types corresponding to the above tribes).  Players themselves are represented by stone figures.  Temple cards will be made available at the side of the board for building throughout the game.  On his or her turn

column5642:
being able to perform most actions as many times as they wish and saving any number of unplayed cards for subsequent turns.

A big component of this game is placing your tribe cards in sets. Skills can only be used if a set of three (or more) cards is at the same location as the player marker. By discarding one of the cards of a set
column5643: the skill may be used.  No matter the tribe

column5645: such as robbing a temple from an opponent

column5648:

column5650:
the game continues until one player reaches 20 points (in which case he or she wins) OR one player subsequently drops below 10 (in which case he or she loses).

supporting the heir in their control as king while trying to take down all of the other heirs.

column5691: This is a very novel take on the old parlor game
column5692: Parcheesi or Sorry or even Trouble
column5693: that many people remember. Players are trying to get their pawns from their starting position around the board into the safe zone. If a pawn is either landed on or passed over by another player's pawn
column5694: the jumped pawn is returned to its starting location. However
column5695: players don't simply roll the dice and move in Zap Zerapp. Instead
column5696: two dice are rolled and results are announced to the table. Players simultaneously start picking up one of the thirteen little wooden containers and shaking them. Inside the containers are one to thirteen lead pellets. Players are trying to select the container with the highest number of pellets
column5697: so long as it doesn't exceed the result of the dice. Once all players have selected their container (the number of pellets are denoted on a sticker on the bottom)
column5698: players move one-by-one from highest to lowest

column5707:
Your goal in 90 Grad is to either push the opponent's "queen" marble from the board or to move your queen to the central square.

Each player starts with seven marbles: one queen
column5708: with the queens being placed in opposite corners of the board
column5710: with these marbles flanking the queen three on each side. On a turn

and the marble moves as many spaces as the number of marbles in the row perpendicular to the direction being moved. Players alternate moves until one of the winning conditions is achieved.

One of Ravensburger's Traveller-Series games.

Loosely translated from a French Game Site:
Alcazar is an abstract strategy game for two players that can be played in as little as 15 - 30 minutes. The object of Alcazar is to either immobilize your opponent's pawn by enclosing it within four walls or to occupy his/her starting square. The game comes with a red and a green pawn
column5722:
and a board with a 4x4 grid of what appear to be castles. Walls can be placed between any two adjacent castles forming a border.

The two pieces begin on their respective starting squares
column5723:
which are located diagonally across the board from each other. Each piece begins surrounded by 4 walls. The object is to move one of the walls on each turn in order to either move your piece to your opponent's starting square or to enclose your opponent's piece so that it can no longer move.

column5756: you miss your go completely. Taking the inside line therefore is quicker
column5757: but makes it easier for others to block you. Each player also has a Joker and Gallop card to help themselves and hinder others once in the game. The races are meant to be quick and the designer encourages betting on them

the game comes packaged in a large wooden box with sliding card lid.

An expansion for the game Svea Rike.

column5782: players bid for the heirlooms in Venetian palaces

column5786: which points which the next auction will be when this one is resolved. Players start with 30 points on the scoring track

and there's a marker to allow debt on the same track. Debt costs double at the game end. There's also a marker to allow you to bribe the auctioneer and take a lot for no cost.

A series price tiles show the potential value of the next completed lot. So you might get to sell your pictures for 16 each

but you might be forced to sell when the price is only 4 each.

The game is totally open
column5789: and you can do the maths to work out the potential benefits to each player

Each pawn moves

The game ends after a player ends up without chips

In 1993 Corona was republished and got a new variant included as 'Orbit' (by Franckh-Kosmos).

providing each player with a special Cosmic power. Each player draws one randomly at game start.

it is a three-player game.

column5868:
Extrapolated from Game Cabinet translation:
The three game mats are placed in the middle of the table. They should be arranged so that every player can easily read the writing on them.

Chips
The chips are also placed in the middle of the table and they form the pool. The pool should be easily reachable for every player. For 4 or 5 players use all the chips
column5869:
for 3 players only use 15 of each color.

Voting tiles
Each player gets 4 voting tiles.
Only one Correction Rule for a given chip color can be in play at a time since they are mutually exclusive. Therefore
column5870:
if two Correction Rules which contradict each other are revealed during set up replace the second with a new card.

The remaining "Correction Rule"
column5871:
"Voting Rule" and "Incident Rule" cards are shuffled together and dealt to the players.

Number of cards per player:

5 players = 6 cards
4 players = 7 cards
3 players = 9 cards
The remaining cards are placed on the (Discarded cards) space of the game mat.

Pencil and Paper
Each player will also need a pencil and a piece of paper. On the paper each player lists his prediction for the first Prediction Round. (i.e. he lists the place that he thinks he will occupy in the standings after the Scoring Round has been completed).

The starting player now takes 7 chips of any combination of colors from the pool. The other players also get 7 chips each according to their seating (not the place cards). The starting player now starts the game.

The game mats and all chips are put into the middle (3 players: 15 chips per color).

The cards are laid out: 2 Correction Rule
column5873: and 2 Incident Rule. The first Scoring Rule is Single + Bonus
column5874:
the first Prediction Rule is Own place = 15 Punkte.

Each player gets 4 voting tiles + 7 chips.

Correction
column5876: and Incident Rule cards are shuffled together and dealt: 5 players = 6 cards
column5878:
3 players = 9 cards.

Everyone gets pencils and paper and writes down their first prediction.

Game Course
The game consists of 5 rounds. Each round is divided into 3 parts:

Move Round(s)
Scoring Round
Prediction Round
In each round players can score points. The player with the most points at the end of the fifth round wins the game.

the player

they can ask that player for a specific card. The player has to show the questioner a Yes/No card to indicate their answer.

they end up in the dungeon. The game ends after a player reaches a certain number of points.

Der Feuersalamander is the third game in Noris' Fantasy trilogy

with Die Drei Magier and Das Blaue Amulett being the first and second.

column5952: as merchants in the time of the Hanseatic League try to carry salt from Lübeck to commercial ports and exchange them for needed products. The exchanged goods must either be brought back for domestic storage (on the storage card) or to trade offices in other harbors
column5953:

On the storage cards each Hansa merchant finds the products that he must in the course of the game

During this time period

column5972:
The object of this game is to make the longest snakes possible.

Each player places a screen in front of themselves. Mix up the snake cards in the game lid with their snake basket showing. The players each take five snake cards and place them behind their screens
column5973:
so that the other players cannot see them.

Players take their turns in clockwise order. The person to play chooses a snake which they would like extend. Usually this will be the longest snake. This player can then add to this snake as many matching cards of one color as they like. The start squares for the snakes are the snake ends in the middle and at the edges of the board. No card may be placed on the four snake baskets. The joker cards can be used for any snake colour. After playing their cards the players draw the required number of cards to restore their hand to five cards. If a player has no cards that can be played they may return their cards and take five new ones.

Snake tunnel
The beige bars in the center of the board and on cards on the board are tunnels. Players may use these to lengthen a snake and gain more points. Cards may not be played over tunnels.
When all the snakes are complete or no more cards can be played the game is over and the player with the most points is the winner.

column6285: 000 Against Persia is a two player wargame covering the Persian civil war from 401-387 B.C. The game is strategic in scale
column6286: with units representing forces of the Persian Empire
column6290:
covers an area corresponding approximately to modern day Balkans to Afganistan.

Game components consist of a mapsheet
column6312: A shot disturbs the eerie silence of a deserted city street
column6313: punctuated by the frantic footfalls of men seeking cover. One of Kruger’s last veteran nco’s lies motionless in the street. The remnants of the dead man’s squad are nowhere to be seen—scattered in nearby houses and gutters—all thoughts of the advance abandoned with the sudden demise of their leader...the compulsion for revenge obviously overcome by their instinct for self-preservation. Off to the right
column6314: Kruger’s own men have located the source of the lethal shot and are laying down a steady stream of fire on the church steeple directly ahead. The absence of responding fire suggests that the lone Russian marksman has beat a hasty retreat or been victimized by the withering fire of the German retort. Kruger has seen enough. He is to occupy the church and set up a regimental observation post at once. His orders leave no leeway for delays by a single sniper. He gives the signal to rush the building. Obedient to their training
column6318: and 18 months of fighting in Russia
column6319: spring to their feet. Seconds later the sharp
column6320:
staccato retort of a Russian machinegun concludes with the assertiveness of death itself that this time Kruger was wrong...

This is Squad Leader...a game of WWII tactical combat in Europe. Now you make the instant decisions resulting in life or death for your men
column6321: victory or defeat for your army...for YOU are the Squad Leader. YOU direct the fire of your squad
column6323: or set your defenses against massed Russian human wave or armor assaults. Will that hedgerow provide adequate cover for your flanking efforts
column6324:
or will your men be cut down by the American machinegun position in the woods? The decision is irrevocable and yours alone. You must live or die by the results.

Squad Leader utilizes programmed instruction to guide you through 12 scenarios of increasing realism and complexity. The scenarios run the gamut from street fighting in Stalingrad to armored advances across snow covered roads in the Ardennes. A Campaign Game ties the individual scenarios together and allows your own personal leader counter to advance in rank and ability. In addition
column6325:
a “Design Your Own” section is included so that players can create an unlimited number of play situations of their own creation.

Each hex in Squad Leader represents 40 meters of real terrain with counters representing individual leaders
column6327: and vehicles or 4 man crews and 12 man squads. Each game turn is divided into two player turns with 8 phases
column6328:
equivalent to two minutes of actual time.

Squad Leader is more than just a game
column6329: it is a game system which can be used to portray any WWII infantry action. Its innovative system does for infantry combat what Panzerblitz and Panzer Leader have done for armored warfare games. Squad Leader provides innovative rules for morale
column6351:
and much more.

Be forewarned! Squad Leader is not an easy game. Do not attempt it without prior wargaming experience. Squad Leader is rated Tournament Level IV on the A.H. Complexity scale.

In each game you get:


520 two-sided ½” die cut counters representing the men and weapons of the German
column6353:
and American armies of WWII.
192 two-sided ⅝” die cut counters representing fortifications and individual vehicles of the combatants.
Big 22” x 28” four section
column6354: full-colour GEOMORPHIC mapboard which can be arranged to make literally hundreds of different terrain configurations that can represent large cities
column6357:
or even the flat plains of the Ukraine.
Comprehensive
column6358:
illustrated 36-page rules of play and designer’s notes booklet.
Scenario cards for the first 12 carefully constructed game situations.
Two highly refined Quick Reference Data Cards which reduce the complexities of a realistic infantry combat game into easily playable proportions.

column6371: players buy and sell shares of stock
column6372:
trying to have the most money at the end of the game.

Each player has a hand of nine cards; eight of them match the company shares that are available for purchase
column6373: while the ninth card is a "Bank Holiday" card. Each of the eight companies has 2-5 shares available
column6374: depending on the number of players
column6375: and each player starts with a randomly drawn share. At the start of the game
column6376: place six movement tiles (numbered 1-6) in one bag and six action tiles (trade x3
column6379:
no action) in another bag.

Each round
column6380: the starting player draws one tile from each bag. If he draws a rank +1 or rank -1
column6381: he moves one share price indicator (a.k.a. "brick") of his choice up or down one rank on the movement track that organizes the company bricks. If he draws a trade
column6382: each player buys and/or sells one share to the bank. Players then simultaneously choose one of the two cards in their hand and reveal them. If no one played a bank holiday card
column6384: the brick associated with each company card advances on the movement track a number of spaces equal to the movement tile drawn
column6385: ignoring occupied spaces. The value of a company's shares depends on the location of its brick on the movement track and its position relative to all of the other bricks. If one or more bank holiday cards were played
column6386:
the bricks move only half the distance or don't move at all.)

Players each draw a new card
column6387: and the bags pass to the next player in clockwise order
column6388: who becomes the starting player for the next round. If a trade tile was drawn
column6389: return all tiles to their respective bags first. The rounds continue until one or more company bricks reach the end of the movement track. At the end of that round
column6390:
players cash out their holdings and whoever has the most money wins.

column6406: One of the more unusual collectible card games on the market
column6407: Doomtown has players taking the part of gangs
column6409: ' trying to gain control of the California boomtown known as Gomorrah
column6410:
in the same Weird West setting as the popular Deadlands RPG. A player wins at the end of a turn if he or she has more victory points + control points than any other player.

Doomtown is set apart from other games in CCG market by its unique poker-based combat resolution
column6411:
as well as by the way in which the town is built up through the game by the use of Deed cards. Outfits range from the good-guy Law Dogs to the mysterious Sioux Union to the nefarious Whateley clan.

A turn is played out over one "day".
In the gambling phase players play a hand of "Lowball" ( Unlike other Doomtown poker hands
column6413:
to determine who will go first for the rest of the turn.
Next in the upkeep phase
column6414:
income is collected and upkeep for Dudes from another outfit are paid for.
The next phase is "High Noon"
column6418:
acting and calling out (all specific actions related to the game play) are taken.
Finally
column6421: the events of the day are discarded
column6422:
players hands are replenished and cards are returned to their "ready" state.

column6432: Tantrix is a strategy game using painted synthetic resin hexagons (often mistakenly thought to be Bakelite). It was invented in New Zealand
column6433: and is clearly derived from the earlier Psyche-paths/Kaliko. Tantrix can be played as solitaire puzzles
column6434: ranging from easy to almost impossible
column6435: or as a multiplayer strategy game featuring a combination of strategy
column6436: luck and skill. Each tile has three tracks on it
column6437: in three different colors (out of four colors). Each track starts on one side of the tile and ends on another. The goal of the game is to create the longest line or loop of your chosen color. If you create a closed loop
column6438:
each tile counts for two points.

Each player has an open hand of six tiles. When it is your turn
column6439: you must first play tiles in any spaces that are "required play" (any hole that has at least three tiles bordering it is a required play). After each played tile
column6440: you randomly draw a new tile. Once you've filled all required spaces
column6441: you play one tile in any legal space. After that
column6442: you once again need to fill required spaces. To play the game well
column6443: you need to create required spaces in smart ways. This way you can both enable yourself to play more tiles during your turn and force your opponent to play tiles that continue your track (remember that your opponent's hand is open
column6444:
so try to create required spaces that take advantage of his tiles).

The full version contains 56 tiles.

Note that there are also smaller solo brain teaser puzzles that are Outside the Scope of BGG. The 10-tile version is a color matching puzzle. Arrange the tiles so that all the colored lines match where the tiles touch each other. Additionally
column6447: and create a closed loop. Begin the easy puzzle by using the first four tiles (which are numbered on the reverse side 1
column6449: 3 & 4). Increase the level of difficulty by adding the fifth tile
column6450:
then 6th tile etc. Comes in Green & Black.

Similar to:

Tantrix Gobble
The Mind Game
Kaliko (Psyche-Paths)

column6465:
and score individual regions. The entire game lasts three Passages and each Passage may contain several turns.

column6481: each player controls a team of dragon hunters (two knights
column6483: and a wizard). Like all dragon hunters
column6484: they have only one goal: gold
column6486:
jewels and magic objects. As for actually killing a dragon? It's a piece of cake. But the most difficult part comes after the dragon is dead: the adventuring party has to figure out how to share the spoils.

As soon as a dragon is overpowered
column6487: then some additional gems are revealed
column6488: and the players who had participated in that hunting party start a negotiation over how to divvy up the gems. If the sixty-second sand timer runs out
column6489: then no one gets treasure. When all of the dragons have been slain and the treasure claimed or discarded
column6490: the game ends and players score for their holdings
column6491: with silver and magic objects worth 1 point each
column6494: and the colored gems scoring 10-15 points for those players who hold more than everyone else. (In the Advanced game
column6495: the colored gems score 8-12 points in addition to a variety bonus of 5 points for each set of different colored gems a player holds. The Black Diamond is worth 19 points [in the 2011 edition]
column6496:
but negates a player's score for all colored gems.)

column6504: PITSTOP is a motor racing board game. 65 special tiles let the player build virtually any circuit they like. The game comes with multilingual rules (english
column6507:
german and french) and instructions to build 10 different F1 circuits.
Each player must set the gear and roll an appropriate number of special dice
column6508: that determine the speed of the car and the fuel consuption. The game is turn based and the phasing player
column6510:
must set the gear for next turn. The box strategy is the most important decision to take. You can decide to complete all the 3 laps without stopping or making one or two pitstops.
The game is not a "simulation"
column6511: but to win you need a good amount of skill. Even if the speed of your car is determined by dice
column6512: you have to choose carefully the "braking point" in order to enter the curves at the best speed. If you exceed the curve's speed limit
column6514: you can simulate a championship playing different circuits. What's interesting is that the game strategy changes from circuit to circuit and if you design your own circuit you need all your "driving skill" to be competitive. Rookies can win
column6515:
but they will find very hard to beat a skilled player.
Game components: 65 tiles to build the circuits (an avarege of 25 tiles are needed for each circuit)
column6542: the game of western gunfights. In Gunslinger
column6543: you play the part of a western character who is caught in a sudden gunfight
column6544:
and you face the split-second decisions and incidents of the showdown as bullets start to fly.

Gunslinger is based on a quick and easy game system that recreates the split-second nature of gunplay. Each turn the players secretly play cards to define exactly what they will do during the next two seconds in the game. Then they step through these actions on the playing map
column6545: resolving each shot in the split-second when it takes place. Gunslinger resolves combat quickly and easily. The attacker draws a result card that shows exactly where his shot hits
column6546: which combines with his gun to determine the damage he inflicts. This recreates the critical differences between weapons: Winchesters
column6550:
Smith & Wesson's breakopen guns and Remington's Derringer are a few of the guns in the game.

Gunslinger includes eight two-sided boards (a total of sixteen map faces) portraying town and countryside terrain at a scale of six feet per hex. These boards can be assembled in varying ways to create a vast number of different maps that are used in the gunfights. The terrain includes gullies
column6555:
hitching posts and the interiors of buildings.

Gunslinger presents 26 different gunfights and several hundred variations
column6556: including both historical gunfights and made-up situations. Wild Bill Hickok
column6559: and John Wesley Hardin are just a few of the real gunslingers of history who appear in re-creations of the gunfights that made them famous.  Indian raids
column6560:
barroom brawls and poker games are just a few of the hypothetical situations.

column6571:
from the translation:

OBJECTIVE

Place one of your pieces on your opponents back row.

THE GAME

The players each stand their pieces on their back rows. They place two balls on each figure. They now take turns and choose one of the following three actions.

1.Move: Players can move the chosen piece as many squares sideways
column6572: forwards or backwards as the piece has balls
column6573:
if it has 4 balls it must move 4 squares. The pieces may neither jump nor change direction.

2.Sharing: Players may take all the balls from a selected piece and place one each on any of their other pieces. Exception
column6574:
if a tower has six balls only five balls may be placed on the other five pieces and so one ball is lost and is removed from the game.

3.Capturing: Only balls are captured
column6575:
not pieces. The capturing piece and the threatened piece stay on their own squares. Example a white piece and a brown piece stand two squares apart. They have two balls and three balls respectively. It is whites move and white can remove the three brown balls from the game as long as there is no piece between the white and brown pieces. Pieces whose balls have been captured can be activated again by the sharing of balls.

Therefore
column6576: capturing only limits the movement possibilities
column6577:
the number of pieces always remains the same. If a player loses all their balls they can no longer move and have lost.
