column6585:
extrapolated from translation

Contents:
15 colored dice
1 special die (grey)
1 board
1 set of rules

Aim of the game
To fill zones of 2 or 3 spaces with dice showing the same number
column6586:
and if possible of the same color. More points are gained if these are also in the same circle.
How the game is played:
This player will throw the dice 5 times in order to place all the dice on the board.
1.The player throws one die of each color along with the special die.
2.The player checks the special die in order to see what possibilities are open to him for changing the outcome of his throw and improving the position. The value of the numbers of the dice does not affect the result.

Explanation of the symbols of the special die:
The side which has two dice drawn on it permits the player to change the number on 1 or 2 of the the 3 dice thrown to match the number showing one of the other die.

The side which has one die drawn on it permits the player to change the number of one of the dice thrown to match the number on one of the other two dice thrown.

The symbol of the 2 half circles with arrow heads allows the user to interchange the position of two dice already placed by him on the board with a view to ending up with a group of dice with the same numbers and
column6588:
of the same color as well.

The symbol of the 3 small squares with a divided arrow coming from middle one allows the player to change the number on a die which has already been placed on the board or which the player is about to place on the board
column6589:
to any other number.

The Flying Turtle is the super bonus. It allows the player to do all the moves which are permitted by the other symbols on the special die. Further more
column6590:
when placed in the center of the board it increases the players points considerably.


3. Once the player's throw has been adjusted to take into account the special die
column6591: the player places his dice in the zone or zones of his choice.  He will in so doing try to fill the empty spaces in a circle with dice with the same numbers and if possible
column6592:
of the same color.

End of the game:
The player who has the highest score after 5 turns wins.

column6602:
from the rules:

Equipment
A board with 32 indented spaces
32 stones of 11 colours (8+7+3+3+2+2+2+2+1+1+1) Two rules booklets.

To Start
At the start of the game
column6603: the 32 stones are spread randomly over the board surface so that all spaces are filled.  The board is set between the players
column6604:
leaving a space in front of each player.

For MEM-Solitaire
column6605:
you need only one playing space and the filled board.

The General Idea
You take stones from the MEM board
column6606: and use them to build patterns of stones in your playing area.  The pattern of stones in your playing area must always "match" some group of stones remaining on the board.  In two-person play
column6607: your opponent will try to take stones that make it easy for him to build matching patterns
column6608:
and make it hard for you to find good matches on the board. The player with the most stones wins.

column6617:
extrapolated from English rules:

A co-operative game for two to six players twelve years old or more.

Contents

A board in two parts
Two colored wooden pieces (Momo and the tortoise Kassiopeia)
12 colored wooden discs (the hour flowers)
84 hexagonal cards and 4 spare cards
- top side : dream pictures or question marks
- under side: green or grey

One day the children notice that people have less and less time. Momo finds out that spooky 'grey men' are tempting people to bring them their time to save it in a time savings bank. In fact they are stealing their time. The more time they save
column6620:
more hurried and poor their existence becomes.

Finally
column6621: with the help of a wonder flower and Master Hora's advice
column6623:
try to beat the grey men and give the people back their time.


Momo and Kassiopeia must find the way to Master Hora and meet each other at the gate to the never-alley. But how? Momo has a dream. She sees a picture that shows the way. Kassiopeia also has a dream. It is as if she goes along a dream street and after a long time meets Momo at the gate to the never-alley.

First
column6624:
the players split into two groups.
One group takes the yellow Momo figure
column6625: all the cards with the yellow edges
column6626:
and one half of the board.
The other group takes the brown Kassiopeia figure
column6627: all the cards with brown edges
column6628:
and the other half of the board.
IMPORTANT:
The two groups don't play against each other but with one another. Each group respects the other and doesn’t make things too difficult or too easy.

The start of the game

The two groups sit apart from each other so that they cannot see the other half of the board
column6629:
preferably on two separate tables.

Each group sorts their cards. The green cards and the grey cards are separated. At first
column6630: only the green cards are used
column6631:
as well as the Gigi and Beppo cards.

Each Group now lays a selected card
column6633:
on a space on the board. But not on one of the three approaches to the never-alley. This card is the start square. Momo and Kassiopeia are placed here on their respective boards.

For the first game
column6634:
the path should not be more than ten cards long. See the illustration.

The storytelling begins

In turn
column6635: each group tells the other a story
column6636: involving the dream pictures on the chosen path.  For each question mark on the path
column6637:
the group thinks up their own imaginary picture.
The other group listens carefully and tries to remember the story.

After the two stories have been told
column6638: the grey cards are placed on the empty squares of the board (colored pictures face up). The whole board is now full of dream pictures and question marks
column6639:
and the original path is no longer clear.

The two groups come together and put the two halves of the board together. Each group now positions itself by the other half of the board and will soon move the figure which goes with that half.

Momo and Kassiopeia run through the city

At last Momo and Kassiopeia set off. Each group moves their figure in turn onto an adjacent space. It is important that all the players should participate by recalling the story they heard and they should all agree which space the figure should move to.
Before either Momo or Kassiopeia is placed on a new card
column6640: the card is turned over.  If the underside is green the card remains turned and the figure steps onto it.  But if it is grey
column6644:
and an hour flower is taken to the time-store of the grey men. Master Hora's flower is left until last.
Momo and Kassiopeia may not step on the grey cards.

Gigi and Beppo help Momo and Kassiopeia. If a group finds one of the friends
column6645: this group may expose any chosen card.  In this case
column6646:
no flower need be given up if the chosen card is grey.

When Momo or Kassiopeia reach the gate to the never-alley
column6647: they wait there for each other and go together to Master Hora.  Master Hora gives them his flower and so Momo and Kassiopeia free all the captured flowers.  The flowers are given back to the people.  Together you have won the game.  If Master Hora has to give up his flower to the grey men no more can be done.  Momo and Kassiopeia

column6732: Players race their rockets to the moon

column6734: the player moves his/her rocket forward by the difference between the cards in fields. If it has the same value
column6735: the player must move another player's rocket by one field. If the played card is lower
column6736: the active player has two options: Either move his/her rocket back the difference
column6737:
or draw the difference in cards (this is the only way of getting new cards).
A round ends when either a player has reached the moon
column6738: or someone runs out of cards
column6739: or the stack is used up. Then each player deducts the number of cards in his/her hands from the number of the field his/her rocket is on
column6740:

column6759: Schraumen is a card game based on a nonsense culture
column6760: enacting nonsensical laws written on scrolls
column6761:
paid for with plums. The name of the game is a portmanteau word from the German Schriftrollen (Scrolls) and Pflaumen (plums).

The 77 scroll cards are shuffled and the top 11 removed from the game without looking at them. Deal each player three scrolls and give each player seven plum tokens
column6762:
which are both money for bidding and victory points at the end of the game.

Each scroll is a rule of the game that must be followed when the scroll is played. If a rule cannot be followed
column6763: the scroll is burned in the fire - that is
column6764: removed from the game.  Examples include
column6765: "Each player must put three plums in the garden
column6766: " if at least one player has fewer than three plums.  Or
column6767: "The player with the most plums must give all other players a plum
column6768:
" if two or more players are tied for having the most plums.

Players take turns reading the scrolls they wish
column6770: all of which involve plum distribution in some way.  You don't have to enact any of your scrolls unless you have more than five
column6771: at which point you MUST activate (or burn
column6772: if illegal) enough to bring your hand down to five cards.  A player then draws a scroll
column6774:
and auctions it off without telling the others what's on it. He may bid for it himself.

The game ends when either all scrolls are taken or when the text of a read scroll requires the game to end. The player with the most plums wins.

column6784: players move their ships over the tiles
column6785: collecting ones which construct treasure chests
column6786: or are used as events. Building a chest of your own colour scores more than tiles of your opponent's colours or plain brown ones. Complete a chest of 4 to 10 pieces
column6787:
score it then start again. Events include flipping tiles on the board and stealing tiles from chests for yourself.

column6799:
Principle of the game:
The players' goal is to conquer the capital of the kingdom of Zargos. Each participant is found at the head of a race : Dragons
column6803:
Amazons.
The world Zargos consists of 5 continents and 11 kingdoms. The central province contains the players' goal: the Forbidden City
column6804: the capital of Zargos. In each game round
column6805: a player can perform attacks (with his troops) from the territories he occupies
column6806:
then rearrange his forces. Controlling a territory give points and these points are used to buy reinforcements and boats. The control of an entire kingdom allows to buy magic cards. These cards have magical effects affecting some aspect of the game. Each race has characteristics and features that confer advantages in combat or reorganization. Combats are resolved with D6 and the results depends on the number of units participating in the fight.

At least in the first edition

Rules: Roll the marbles onto the board. You can swing
column6899:
drop or spin a marble onto the board. Ignore the rules for removing marbles until all of the marbles have a home on the board.

The youngest player starts. He takes the big marble and rolls it onto the board. He should try to push opponent's marbles to the inside and his own to the outside. Let the ball roll around until all marbles settle.

End of a turn: At the end of the turn if a player has a majority of marbles in the innermost circle
column6900:
that player must remove a marble. Only one marble is removed per turn and the owning player chooses which to remove.

If there is no obvious majority (2 or more players are tied) in the innermost circle
column6901: no marble is removed. If there are no marbles in the innermost circle
column6902: then consider the marbles in the next circle out. If there is a majority
column6903: a marble will be removed. If there are no marbles in the inner two circles
column6904: then look at the 3rd circle out. If the third circle is empty
column6905:
no marbles will be removed. Check for removing marbles at the end of each turn.

End of Game: A player with no more marbles is out of the game.

Last player to have marbles on the board wins.

Theme
In this simple card game players are Chicago era mobsters trying to make off with briefcases full of stolen loot. But careful
column7113:
some of those briefcases might explode...

Aim of the game
Collecting the most points by collecting "explosive cards" with high values.

Game play
There are four sets of 8 cards
column7114:
each with values from 1-8. Each player gets a set of one colour.
The explosive cards show briefcases with positive values from 1-8 on one side
column7115: and bombs with negative values from 1-8 on the other side. They are shuffled and a number of explosive cards equal to the number of players plus one are laid out
column7116:
positive side up. The remaining explosive cards are set aside.

Players try to win as many positive explosive cards as possible. They take turns placing one of their number cards in front of one of the explosive cards. Whoever places the highest total on each explosive cards gets to take that card.

Rules for card placement:

You cannot play another card directly on top of one of your own cards.
Each number can only be played once per explosive card
column7117: i.e. if another player has already played the 4 on an explosive card
column7118:
you cannot play a 4 on the same explosive.
8 is an exception; there is no restriction on how many 8s can be played on one explosive card.


If there are already 7 number cards on an explosive card
column7119: a player can blow it up by adding an 8th card. The explosive card is then turned from its briefcase side to the bomb side
column7120:
and the player who wins it gets negative points instead.

A round ends when all players have played all their cards. Card values on each explosive card are added up
column7121:
with the last card in a row earning its owner an extra two points. The player with the most points in one row wins that explosive card.

Players get back their number cards and a new round starts with new explosive cards.

The game ends when all explosive cards are gone or there aren't enough left to start another round.
Players add up the points from all their positive and negative explosive cards. The player with the highest total wins the game.

Goal

Game play
The 54 coin cards have values from 1 to 19 printed on both sides. The value on one side differs from that of the other side by a maximum of two.
The goal of the game is to collect series of four coins with consecutive values (e.g. 1-2-3-4 or 9-10-11-12). Series of four are exchanged for victory point cards. There are 12 victory point cards with values from 18 to 7. The first player to collect a series gets the 18-point victory card

column7440: Poker is played with a standard deck of 52-cards
column7441: and sometimes Jokers are added as wild cards. The object of the game is to win the pot which contains all the bets the players have made in a deal.  Players are dealt cards which are usually reduced to a Poker hand of five (5) cards. Betting and bluffing are used in rounds until all bets are squared up
column7442: or until all other players have conceded the pot (folded). If all bets have been squared up
column7443:
the rounds are followed by a "showdown" in which all hands are fully revealed; the one with the best combination of a Poker hand of five (5) cards being the winner.

The following table describes and ranks the standard Poker hands:

Five of a Kind (Only if wild cards are in use): Four cards of the same rank and one wild card (eg: A
column7447:
Joker).
Straight Flush: A straight with all cards of the same suit (eg: A
column7451:
10: all spades). (The highest Straight Flush is nominally called a Royal Flush)
Four of a Kind: Four cards of the same rank (eg: A
column7455:
K).
Full House: Three of a kind in one rank and a pair in a different rank (eg: A
column7459:
K).
Flush: Five cards of the same suit (eg: A
column7463:
9: all spades)
Straight: Five cards in sequence of rank (eg: A
column7467:
10).
Three of a Kind: Three cards of the same rank (eg: A
column7471:
Q).
Two Pair: Two pairs of different ranks (eg: A
column7475:
Q).
One Pair: A pair of cards of the same rank (eg: A
column7479:
J).
High Card: High card without any other higher combination (eg: A

column7632:
This is a strategy game for 2-3 players. It takes place on a 6 sided game board with pieces moving on the triangles. Each player has 4 pawns in the form of dice. The triangular fields of the board are molded so that a corner of a die exactly fits in. The die can be moved from space to space with a simple nudge at the top.

Object of the game is to get your 4 dice across the board.

PREPARATION FOR THE GAME WITH TWO ? The younger player chooses a color and puts his 4 dice into four edge spaces of his side of the board.

WHAT DOES A TURN CONSIST OF?

1.) Each turn must be executed completely. One might not skip a part of the turn. You may not move a die less than its actual movement unless you reach the finish without completing your die roll
2.) Dice may not touch. So a die will block 3 spaces. (2 spaces if on an edge.)
3.) If a player has no legal move
column7633:
he skips his turn.

GAME RULES FOR THREE PLAYERS All rules of the normal game for two persons are valid also for the game with three.
Additionally you must follow these rules: 1.) Set up is different . See rules for proper 3 person set up.

The third and fourth dice of each player may only be moved
column7634:
when the first and second dice have reached the finish.

anyway. Except maybe to throw the others off track about which color is yours ...

When all movement is done

column7665: this time adding the numbers together to see how far a shot goes. If you get blank

column7744: Quest for Power is billed as a "Game Masterless Role-Playing System". In actuality

column7771: Domain is very similar in nature to Dungeonquest from Games Workshop. The goal of the game is to reach the Treasure Chamber in the center of the board and escape back out again with some of the valuable artifacts contained therein.  There are two ways the game can end.  One way is that once someone escapes the dungeon with one of the Warlock's artifacts

Each appropriate symbol rolled (axes or arrows) counts as a "hit". Scoring more hits than the target has hit points removes some of the units (miniatures) from the target army. column8363:
extrapolated from Schildberg translation:

Preparation
• Place the card tray in the middle of the table.
• Shuffle the cards and place them face down in one side of the card tray to form the draw pile.
• Roll the three dice and place them next to the card tray.
• Give each player 10 chips worth a total of 270 points
column8364: as follows: 7 light green chips worth 10 each
column8366:
and 1 black chip worth 100.

Play
• The player who has been the luckiest today begins the game. Play then proceeds clockwise.
• A player’s turn must always be taken in this order (during which steps 1 – 4 may repeat several times):
1. Turn over a card. The cards show what dice must be rolled in step 3.
2. Put down a chip. Then the player decides — based on the card and the intended dice roll — which chip he would prefer to put down. You can only put down one chip per card (one 10-point chip
column8367:
one 50-point chip or one 100-point chip). Place it in the middle of the table next to the exposed card.
3. Bet and roll the dice. Now the player must predict the total roll of the respective dice on the card when compared with the numbers currently showing on the dice.
4. Evaluate the roll. The player’s bet will be right or wrong. Right bets mean two possibilities for this player:
• He/she may take another turn
column8368:
going through steps 1 – 4 again.
• Or he/she may end his/her turn. He/she takes all the upturned cards from the middle of the table
column8369:
puts them in a stack in front of him/her and puts the chips from the middle of the table on the stack.

The game ends when only one player has chips left. This player gets one final turn. If he/she bets wrong
column8370:
the chips are left in the middle of the table; nobody can use them in the scoring. The same goes for chips that were not yet used in betting.

The game also ends if no more cards can be drawn. In this case chips not yet used in betting do not score
column8371:
either.

Scoring and winning
Each player scores his/her stacks separately
column8372: by multiplying the number of cards in the stack by the total value of the chips in the stack. Then add the separate stack scores together for a grand total. The winner is the player with the highest grand total. In case of a tie
column8373:
the player with the most cards wins.

column8393: for instance). Players roll a die and move one of their pawns forward to the best possible positions in the next rank ahead of them. Some fields allow for instant promotions or demotions of others
column8394: or for additional rolls. Other fields allow a player to add a minister to the current cabinet. The first player to control three ministers becomes chancellor
column8395: losing his/her post only when another player has more ministers. If all minister posts are taken
column8396:
a player placing a minister removes another player's minister and takes his/her place.
Whenever a player cannot use his/her die result
column8397: s/he ages by one year. A player reaching the age of 65 is forced to retire from the game - when all players are retired
column8398:
the player who holds the office of chancellor is the winner.

column8406:
extrapolated from rules:

Movies & Money
A game for 2 – 4 players
Ages 8 and up
Manufactured by Jumbo

Game materials
Game board
25 miniature screens
25 movie cards
6 Golden Suns
2 special dice
Play money

Preparation
Place the board on the table. Each player sits on one side of the board. The red
column8408:
yellow or blue strip at the board’s edge determines the color each player uses.

A player is chosen to be banker. He distributes to each player 1 million dollars (5 x $10
column8412:
000). He puts the remaining money beside the board and administers it separately from his own money.

The 25 movie cards are mixed thoroughly and a card is put face down on each board space.

The 25 miniature screens and the 6 Golden Suns are put beside the board.

Everyone throws the numbered die once. The player with the highest result (the star equals 6) begins. The game proceeds after him clockwise.

Play
column8414: a player throws both dice. The intersection of the column (number-die) and row (letter-die) determines a board space. If the movie card on this space is face down
column8415: the player can and should buy this space with this card. He pays $10
column8416: 000 to the bank and turns the card face up. Now
column8417:
a miniature screen is put on this space. The player takes a screen from the reserve and puts it on the space so that his color appears through the two gaps in the framework of the screen.

Finally
column8418: the acquired movie card is put into the screen
column8420:
phase 2
As soon as all 25 movie cards are owned and face up in miniature screens on the board
column8421:
the second game phase begins. Now movie cards can change hands.

Debts and bankruptcy
If a player must pay a sum and no longer has sufficient cash
column8422: he must sell his movie cards and/or Golden Suns. The player chooses what he would like to sell. The bank pays the sums printed on the cards
column8423: and Golden Suns fetch the same amount. Sold movie cards are turned face down again
column8424: and the screens and Golden Suns go back to the reserve. How-ever
column8425:
the bank only takes back cards and Golden Suns if a player is insolvent.

A player who cannot settle his debts must declare bankruptcy. He gives all his remaining cash
column8426: miniature screens and Golden Suns back to the bank. The movie cards are turned face down again. The player retires from the game. If movie cards are turned face down in the second game phase
column8427: the game returns to the first game phase. Therefore
column8428:
takeovers of movie cards that belong to other players cannot take place.

Negotiations
All players are allowed to negotiate with other players anytime
column8429: even if it is not their turn. Movie cards may be bought
column8430:
sold or traded. Players can also negotiate in order to pay debts. They need not necessarily sell to the bank if they receive better purchase offers from players. Players can also negotiate whether owed sums on opponents’ movie cards can be reduced or even free of charge.

Ending the game
The game is over when only one player remains. He is king of Hollywood!

column8464:
PROCESS OF GAME
The player whose turn it is draws one tile from the bag and places it on any free space.
The colour on top is decisive for the effect of the tile. All tiles in the distance that corresponds to the colour (straight line) are turned upside down. Diagonal distances do not count here. Violet (zero) up means of course that nothing is turned. Only a just placed tile can have an effect
column8465:
there are no chain reactions.
Example: If I lay down a tile with orange up
column8466: all tiles that are exactly two spaces away from that tile are turned around
column8467:
but not those who are one or more than two spaces away. The games lasts until all tiles are placed and the board is completed.

from the rules translation
OBJECT OF THE GAME
At the end of the game every player counts separately the number of tiles showing his two colours on the top. Now he subtracts the lower number from the higher one. That is his final result.
Example: With red and green as my colors
column8468:
eight red tiles are tying up and three green ones. Thus I have five points.
If the final result
column8469: of two players is the same
column8470:
the player with more tiles up (sum of the two colours) wins the game.

column8727: two-player card game Blink bills itself as the fastest game in the world. Without taking turns
column8728: players race to empty their hands by matching the color
column8730: or number of symbols on their cards in hand to the top card of the two discard piles in the center of the table. As soon as a player lays down one card
column8732: up to the hand size of three cards. If both players can't play
column8733:
they can both draw a card directly onto the discard pile at the same time and then continue play. The first player to empty their hand and draw pile wins.

column8746: with all of the objects on a card having the same color
column8751: and shadings come in three different types: green
column8754:
shaded and outlined.

All players compete simultaneously and try to claim sets of cards in a single pass through the deck. A set consists of three cards that are either all alike or all different in each attribute. For example
column8755: if all three cards have the same number of objects
column8759: then those cards are a set; if two of the cards have a common attribute that is not shared by the third
column8760:
they are not a set.

To play
column8761: one person takes the deck and lays out twelve cards face up. The first person to spot a set collects those three cards; if the player was mistaken
column8762: then this player cannot claim a set until after another player has done so. After someone has claimed a set
column8763: the cardholder lays out three more cards. (If all players agree that no sets can be claimed
column8764:
then the cardholder lays out three more cards. These cards aren't replaced after someone claims a set.) Whoever claims the most sets wins!

they all relly on cards that have 4 different objects in 4 different colors on them. In the course of the game cards are set next to one another following the placement rules. Whoever gets rid of their cards first wins.

Players buy a car

column8878: Card game in which players purchase companies using sets that have various monetary denominations (the resource cards).  Turning in a set with matching symbols is worth more than the face value of the cards
column8879: so set collecting becomes a key strategy.  Purchased companies (the corporation cards) are placed in front of the player according to a matching letter system.  The top company of each stack is vulnerable to proxy take-overs by other players
column8880:
so they usually attempt to order their holdings such that the most valuable ones are covered by less valuable companies. Scoring occurs whenever a player draws a profit card from the deck. The game ends when the corporation deck is exhausted.

Originally published by 3M (3M Gamette Series)
column8881:
re-published by Avalon Hill in its "gamette line" (gamette no. 205) when they took over 3M's line. Schmidt published the German edition DIE BOSSE in 1991.

""
column8890:
Big Deal is a game of corporate business deals. Players are big investors (and I mean big - the smallest notes are $50 million and billions of dollars change hands) and wheeler-dealers.

Players acquire shares in companies
column8892: but also possibly through purchase of other players' previous sales. To form the companies they must also acquire resources
column8893: which are bought from 4 sets. The pricing mechanism for these is like Palmyra and McMulti - each purchase increases the price and each sale decreases it. Once an appropriate set is acquired for a matching set of (at least two) shares in a company
column8894: the company can be formed. Companies pay income to their owners each turn. They can also be sold off at a premium
column8895: or split up (provided the owner has enough shares and resources) to gain double income. The real heart of the game comes in the option to conduct hostile takeovers. A player lays one or more shares in a company owned by another player and then starts a bidding war to takeover the company. Each player is bidding to buy the shares of the opponent (bids are per share). The "winner" gets the company and all the shares
column8896: the "loser" is paid off at the final bid price. Who is actually the winner and loser depends
column8898:
on the balance of the final price.

There is a sudden death variable finish
column8900:
so there is a tense few final rounds when players can try to realize assets while they are still valuable. During this period the judgment of takeover prices becomes even more tricky (and a gamble).

column8917: Pax Britannica: The Colonial Era 1880 to the Great War
column8927: Pax Britannica is a Victorian Era multi player wargame of empire
column8929: and global confrontation. The Great Powers of United Kingdom
column8936: and Japan vie throughout the world for the wealth and esteem conferred by vast colonial holdings in the far-flung corners of the Earth. Each player maneuvers his administrative and military assets to establish control over the choicest and most strategic areas
column8937: keeping a wary eye toward encroaching opponents whose colonial ambitions are every bit as great. Conflict between national wills is more often resolved through peaceful negotiation than through war; but when national honor is too severely tried
column8938:
war can occur- on a scale that threatens to evolve into the War to End All Wars!

Time scale = 4 years per turn; Map scale = abstract; Unit scale = Corps/Fleet
column8940:
Regiment/Squadron; Playing time = approx 4 to 7 hours.

column8951: you control a bunch of religious fanatics who aim to dominate the entire United States of America. Your faction consists of cultists
column8955:
and their plans for domination include such goals as the creation of a continuous chain of lunatics that stretches from coast to coast.

Cults Across America is not a serious simulation. Rather
column8956: it allows players of all stripes to have a good time for a few hours
column8957: whether they aim to crush their competitors using deep-thinking strategy
column8962:
and destroy.

Three Games in One
There are three different ways to play Cults Across America.

The Standard Game
This is the normal game. It is intended for players who don’t mind taking a few hours to play a game but who like a strong dose of the beer and pretzels factor
column8963:
even if it means their painstakingly enacted strategic schemes are occasionally foiled by a player who manages to win the Mythos 500.

The Strategic Game
This is similar to the Standard Game
column8964:
but removes some of really weird stuff. It allows more conventional board gamers to concentrate on sane strategies and not get too disturbed by wandering madness.

The Bloodbath Scenario
This is Cults Across America on steroids
column8965:
and can be played in as little as an hour. The rule set is reduced somewhat so players don’t have to get all concerned about resource management and other fiddly details. The victory conditions are simple too: you win by stomping the hell out of anything that’s not on your side. Last man (or whatever) standing takes the day.

Cults Across America has a Cthulhu Mythos theme.

One player takes a card on which a picture is displayed which is also on the game board. The next player may ask one question which can only be answered with yes or no. In clockwise order the next player may ask a question and so on...
Whether the answer to the question is yes or no

column9055: so also 15 quest-ons that can be asked at maximum. It's forbidden to ask a question about the location of the picture on the game board. In stead of asking a question

a player may also say what picture is on the card when he thinks he knows it.
If he is right

and also a victory point.

""
column9116: Labyrinth (formerly The aMAZEing Labyrinth) has spawned a whole line of Labyrinth games. The game board has a set of tiles fixed solidly onto it; the remaining tiles that make up the labyrinth slide in and out of the rows created by the tiles that are locked in place. One tile always remains outside the labyrinth
column9117: and players take turns taking this extra tile and sliding it into a row of the labyrinth
column9118:
moving all those tiles and pushing one out the other side of the board; this newly removed tile becomes the piece for the next player to add to the maze.

Players move around the shifting paths of the labyrinth in a race to collect various treasures. Whoever collects all of his treasures first and returns to his home space wins!

Labyrinth is simple at first glance and an excellent puzzle-solving game for children; it can also be played by adults using more strategy and more of a cutthroat approach.

column9127:
Ages 5 to 8.
Each player is trying to spend as much time as possible in the amusement park. The player who'll take longest to go through the attractions and leaves last wins. (So this is a reverse race) Cards can be picked up and used to move back or to force the other players forward
column9139: Six telephones are placed around the board and connected over seven hexagonal tiles through a spaghetti-like maze of wires.  A die is rolled to determine a start phone. The players follow the tangled lines with their eyes -- no fingers
column9140: please!  The first player to figure out which telephones are connected wins a telephone chip
column9141:
and the first player to collect six chips wins the game.

A "perceptual dexterity" game for Ages 6-12.

""
column9149:

The players simultaneously bet on meal cards; if you bet correctly (i.e. nobody else bet on that particular meal)
column9150: you move up around the table

column9152: the more you advance.  Some of the meal cards have a ghost on their back; if you win one of those
column9153: you move back instead of forward.  You also have a silver platter; you can use that to send the ghost to another cat --but he'll then have the silver platter for later

and you won't...

One final note: when multiple players bet on the same meal
column9155: their betting tokens remain on the card for the next betting round --this mechanic forces the implicated players to choose something else
column9156:

Simple and fast playing.

column9167:
designing the races you will control and trying to win over the world. The board is an unadorned hex map. Pieces are nicely-made round counters and there are also quite a few beautifully-illustrated cards. Players win by killing enemy creatures or managing to acquire special items/points.

Fast to learn

and forty-five minutes or more to play (shorter or longer depending on specific victory goals and optional rules used).

""
column9179: "A family game of knights in search of the magical ring
column9180:
set in the age of myths."

Each of the four states of Tirad
column9182: Galad and Elgad has one large city.  Life in a city flourishes for the inhabitants only when the magical ring is there.  Unfortunately
column9183:
the ring never stays long in one place. A band of brave knights is gathered together in Galad where they hear rumours that the ring has been seen in Tirad. The Quest begins...

Each player tries to find the ring and transport it to the cities. As a reward
column9184:
they receive the seals of these cities. Collect three different seals to win. Many obstacles are to be overcome and dragons slain before a knight's quest is complete.

This is a fairly abstract game. Each player has three extra "lives" and loses one when defeated by a dragon or when attacking another player. These lives are replenished by visiting cities. The ring allows its bearer some significant advantages such as passing through obstacles. Special spots on the map allow new obstacles to be placed or existing ones to be moved
column9185:
so a player can be affected even by other players far from him. The end game can drag a bit as all the other players coordinate their efforts against the leader.

column9194: Uses an 8x8 board with the 12 corner squares taken out. The pieces are nesting Russian dolls (8 each of small
column9196: for 24 pieces per player). Reminiscent of Halma
column9197:
the pieces attempt to cross the board and re-form on the opposite side. You only move the topmost of any Russian doll stack and you must land on an empty space or on top of a smaller piece. Checkers-like jumping is also possible.

The clever part is that pieces underneath others are out of reach
column9198:
thus you immobilize enemy pieces by covering them ... until you move away.

Ages 8 and up. 2 or 4 players (not playable by 3).

column9211:
Designer/Publisher's Description:

The object of Stonewall is to race your opponents from your starting point to your diagonally opposite corner of a 144 square grid board and back again by the roll of the dice. Every time you move you may place one wall piece of any length (single
column9212: double or triple)on the playing board to help your path or hinder your opponent.  Rolling a four will get you an extra turn and landing on an occupied square will send your opponent back to the start.  Once you have made it to your opposite corner on the turn you pass around it you must change one wall that has already been placed
column9213:
this can be done to speed up your path home or to force an opponent to go backwards if they are winning.
Stonewall has great strategy play patterns but the dice play throws the element of luck into it. As a two player game Stonewall is very competitive yet as a four player game it is very social. New Zealand Consumer Magazine has rated us as the top game in there December 2000 issue after having the game independently play tested
column9214:
and we are now starting to sell thousands throughout New Zealand.

The guns are deployed along the side of the board and are used to fire at and destroy enemy tanks.  Because the guns are deployed secretly to conceal their ranges of fire

Bandu is based upon the game of Bausack. Each player is given a base block and a number of beans. During a turn

Description of Sac Noir (Rio Grande Games
column9240:
2-8 players):
There are five variations on how to play. The goal in all of them is to build a tower. The bag contains very different wooden pieces (i.e. an ashlar
column9243: a fir tree etc.) as well as a sack of beans for the "auction variation" of the game. Depending on the variation you choose
column9244:
either each player builds his own tower or all build one together. The "auction variations" are the most suspenseful and surprising. One might end up spending quite some beans to avoid building an especially difficult element. Gambling and bluffing abilities are needed just as much as a feeling for statics and construction skills. It's a game with almost endless building possibilities. It's a challenge for steady hands and shaky suspense for clever tacticians.

Five cards are drawn. Each card contains a "class" and a list of "categories". A category is selected for each class and the players and five letter tiles are drawn. column9325: The eternal turning of the seasons has come full cycle once again. Spring in the hight country enters with a wash of fresh green and the warming chinook
column9326: while the show still lies deep on the mountain peaks. As the snow recedes

the birds sing loudly in the pines. Spring is the true beginning of the new year in the awakening wilderness of the Yellowstone.

The old buck raises his head and turns his gaze to the horizon. The time has come - now to lead the herd to the summer pasture where the bounty of this land will drive away the hunger of winter past. But other animals have come forth from their dens with the spring - the coyote

column9335: seeking to cross the migratory paths of the other grazing masses. As the young gambol and explore

he takes the first step toward the future.

column9453: and each player writes the answer down on a paddle; when released

The trivia game of general knowledge questions. Updated with questions current to the mid-to-late 1990s.

column10152:
Game about the Crusades. Player move their armies through Europe towards Jerusalem. Play cards to move through specific terrain. Plunder cities to gain gold which can be used at other cities to purchase more troops. The player that conquers Jerusalem is the winner.

A nice new mechanism is the Combat Tower: a cardboard and plastic tower containing horizontal levels with holes. Drop all battling armies in the top: everything that comes out at the bottom fights. Armies that do not fall through stay in the tower until dislodged by armies from a following battle.
column10162:
Netrunner is a cyberpunk-themed collectible card game. The two players are the Corp (who wins by completing Agendas) and the Runner (who wins by infiltrating the Corp and liberating Agendas).

Each side has a limited number of both actions and bits (money) to spend per turn; bits are gone once used
column10163:
and actions must be spent to gain more.
An important thing when evaluating the power of cards is to see the Bit per action ratio.

One unique feature of this game is that the Runner physically moves on the "board" created by facedown Corp cards. It has the feel of a "capture the flag" game
column10164:
with the Runner moving in dataforts to steal Agendas from the Corp.

Another unique feature is that the Cards are NOT the primary strategy of the game; in fact
column10165:
players can win by simply "playing with the rules" itself (a concept difficult to understand if you've never played Netrunner).

Both players play as both Corp and Runner in a game
column10167:
with each player's Runner going against the opponent's Corp. A winning match provides 10 points and the loser scores points equal to the number of agenda points scored/liberated. The winner of the game is the one who has the most points in the 2 submatches.

Though Netrunner is traditionally a two-player duel
column10168:
there are formats that allow for more players (called "The Big Sell Out").

""
column10179: Cosmic Wimpout is "More than an Experience
column10180: It's a game!" In the family of push-your-luck dice games that garners great love
column10181:
mostly through word-of-mouth marketing. It was a cult-game phenomenon in the Grateful Dead universe. The game flourished with the help of college students and Deadhead fans.

You play by rolling the five Cosmic Wimpout cubes and get points for each 5
column10183: or Flash (triplet) that you roll. You can accumulate points towards the winning total by ending your turn or risking it all
column10184: because if you roll and don't score
column10185: you lose all the points for that turn
column10186: and the next player goes. Thus like life
column10188: and sometimes you wimp out." After certain results
column10189: a player may choose to end his turn
column10190: scoring the points he has accumulated. The first player to reach an agreed-upon score wins (300-600 for a short game with scores kept on paper
column10191: 1000-1500 more typically on the game boards)
column10192:
and the game can fit into a small dice tube.

Throughout the years
column10193:
several variations of dice designs have made early versions of the game collectible. There are several silk-screened fabric boards that vary the game length and require the player to use a personalized or improvised pawn.

Numerous variants and house rules exist
column10194: and players are encouraged to change the rules (by unanimous agreement)
column10204:
A cute game for 5-10 year olds.
You are a squirrel running around the forest in a figure-eight track
column10205: picking up pine cones to bring back to your hoard (which you can enter once every lap).  The first squirrel to gather 15 pine cones in his hoard wins.  Spaces on the track give you one to three pine cones when you land on them
column10206: and the special die makes you lose your move now and then --instead
column10207:
every squirrel gets a free pine cone.
The tricky part is that your wheelbarrow tips over and loses its contents whenever you exceed its capacity: six pine cones. Every other squirrel laps the track in the opposite direction to yours
column10208: so there are plenty of squirrel encounters.  Every time you leap over another squirrel (going one way or the other)
column10209:
you can steal from or give to him up to three of your cones. Therein lies all the strategy.

""
column10218: Players represent early Christians arguing over the actual precepts of their Church. The game mechanism involves collecting worshipers to your side
column10219: gaining money and influence over different factions
column10220: and you can win by reaching different goals. As the game proceeds
column10232:
A map of the Mediterranean features cities linked by lines. Move Ulysses' ship along these lines to four secret destinations to win the game.

Players accept the lead player's choice of direction or object and challenge this destination. Alternative destinations are proposed and one winner will emerge. It is important to be the lead player
column10233:
as this person has a choice of actions that no other players have.

""
column10243: Krakatoa is one of the most unusual dice games ever released. The dice are divided into three sets of three
column10249: each die face contains not a number
column10250: but a colored dot of yellow
column10252:
or blue.

The game lasts six rounds
column10253: with each player taking five successive rolls of the dice and scoring after each roll. After the first roll of each round
column10254: the player must pick up a specific set of dice
column10257: striking at least one of the dice still on the table. Skill in precise dice rolling can result in a high score. Players receive points for different combinations
column10258:
such as a set showing all yellow sides for ten points. Strategy comes into play as certain target scores and scoring combinations can result in large bonuses.

""
column10276: and a vampire. Each player has a small board in front of themselves with all 8 characters on it. There is also a deck of cards each showing only 7 characters at a time. Flip a card and whoever calls out the missing character first gets the card. The person with the most cards when they are all gone
column10277:
wins. Recomended for 5 years of age and up.

""
column10289: Confusion. There are 3 dice: a color die
column10291: and an action die. Each die has a background color and some other piece of information. If the word on the word die and the color on the color die don't match
column10292:
be the first to throw out a card of the color that is missing (there are only 3 colors total). If they do match perform the action on the action die. Collect the most points by not being last or freezing up. There is also a variant that complicates things further.

""
column10303: A game with a modular board in which landtiles can be moved around on a sea
column10304: hence Pangea. There are five different tile types
column10305: for each of which there is a tribe that can produce goods there. Each player has tribes in only three types. A tile has a maximum number of inhabitants
column10306:
no production takes place if there are more tribes on a tile.

The game is won by obtaining amulets
column10307: these can only be bought from opposing tribes which are currently producing. Amulets increase the magical power of a player. Magic can be used create new tribes or move neutral ones around
column10308:
but can also be used to move landtiles around.

""
column10317:
The card game loosely based on the board game Auf Achse.

Players get 10 cards each. Cards are either distance cards (10km - 120km) or action cards. The action cards are Freight Lost (-50 cards)
column10320: Really Free Ride (triangle with +2). They lay
column10322: one card in front of them for their distance traveled (run)
column10323: and one in the center for the kilometer counter. Players must have their runs in increasing order
column10324:
with at most one rest card in between.

When the kilometer counter (center cards) reaches a certain limit (depending on the number of players) the stage is over. Players add up their runs. Five stages are played in a game and winner is player with highest run totals over the five stages

""
column10332: The circular game board consists of 24 spaces
column10333: each with three sections. The spaces are valued from 100 to 2400. Each space is available for sale. In a preliminary round
column10334: players may buy two spaces. Then the regular game is played in a series of rounds. Players try to reach spaces with the highest value. The player who does so wins the round
column10335: collects money from the other players
column10336: and may buy another space. The winner is the player who owns six spaces or has the most cash
column10337:
depending on the way the game ends.

""
column10342: 1826: Railroading in France and Belgium from 1826
column10347: 1826 is an 18xx game set in France and Belgium and reflects the full period of Franco-Belgian railroading
column10348: from the origins to the present day. Both countries developed their railroad systems under close Government supervision and this is reflected in the game. The two major French nationalizations are covered
column10349:
as are the post-war electrification and the introduction of high-speed rail (the TGV).

1826 is a moderately complex game
column10350: designed for experienced players who are looking for something different than the usual round of 1830
column10351: 1856 and 1870. Due to the nature of the French political environment
column10352: this is not a game for extensive stock market manipulations
column10353:
nor is it primarily a game of financial management. 1826 is an operationally-centered game in which technology management--getting the right trains on the right companies--is key.

Companies are incrementally funded
column10354: and can buy and sell their own stock. Companies start out as five-share companies and can convert to ten-share companies upon reaching their destination. The first four train classes
column10358: 6 or 10) rather than cities: the last two train classes
column10360: have a range in cities. There are two merger corporations
column10361:
one of which may form relatively early (when the green tiles become available) and the other somewhat later (its first opportunity to form is when brown tiles become available).

""
column10372:
To be the produced version of Aquarium Derby. The board is covered with hexes containing arrows. A player plays the movement card lying facedown in front of themselves then chooses a new one for NEXT turn. Each movement card describes movement relative to the arrow on your current space. The biggest problem is that you are frequently not on the space you were on when you played that movement card

The cool part are the action points which can be used over the course of the game a la Trip Tickets in Wildlife Adventure to save yourself and hose everyone else in further ways. It also adds a touch of a puzzle element as there are usually a couple of ways to save yourself from a bad situation.

From the box:

WARHAMSTER RALLY™ is the crazy racing game based on the award-winning DORK TOWER™ comic strips by John Kovalic. Players take on the rols of Dork Tower characters and compete for the ultimate prize in thoroughbred racing:

THE WARHAMSTER CUP!

What
column10373:
you thought this involved horses?

In WARHAMSTER RALLY
column10375: trying desperately to control their wild Warhamsters on the racetrack
column10379:
and the most ferocious monsters of all... the other players!

""
column10388: players take on the role of explorers in uncharted Africa. The circular playing counters are placed upside down in random locations upon the various circles of the board. Each turn the player may elect to move his explorer to a revealed location anywhere on the board
column10392: or 2 adjacent revealed spaces. The explorer may then take an action (such as reveal an unrevealed tile
column10393: or move various revealed tiles to other locations). The tiles represent trade goods (of various sets)
column10398: and monuments. When the 11th monument is revealed
column10399:
the game ends. Players tally up their points and the player with the most points wins.

This being a Knizia game
column10400: there are various methods of scoring the revealed tiles
column10404:
and end points.

Awarded "Best Family Game" title by Games Magazine in 2002.

""
column10413: silly party game comprised of several subgames
column10414:
all built around a goofy name theme.

""
column10422: The title means "On the wrong track" and
column10424: that's just where you can find yourself.  Players compete to take either the most or the fewest tricks
column10425: depending on the total value of a few hidden cards played at the beginning of each hand.  Problem is
column10427:
players aren't sure whether most or least is good until after all 4 cards are revealed...

""
column10441: Players explore a castle made up of tiles that are solid on three corners and pivot on the fourth corner
column10442: creating a "trapdoor".  On your turn you can move as many spaces as you want until you voluntarily stop or fall into one of these trapdoors.  The object of the game is to have each of your three knights collect a pair of family portraits that are located in the corner "Portrait Galleries" and then make it to the middle of the board where the Treasury is located.  The first player to get all three knights there
column10443:
wins.

The memory element comes into play as you try to remember which paths are the safest route to take as you collect your portraits.

""
column10454: The players are wizards who control five goblins each. Each wizard is trying to be the first to get one of his goblins to the top of the magic mountain. This is done through card play. Two or three numbered cards may be played per turn. The first card determines which goblin moves. The second/third cards determine how far the goblin moves. Goblins ascend the five-tier
column10455: 3-D board by landing on top of another goblin. There are also special event tiles that can help or hinder players
column10457:
which can increase the number of cards in a player's hand.

""
column10467: In The Dog's Meow – originally published as Anderland ("change country") – everything is different: Chocolate tastes like strawberry and barking dogs sound like cats. If one wants to look up
column10469:
and everything red is suddenly blue! Cross-thinking and a quick mind are called for in the fantasy world of the different thinkers. Whoever adjusts most quickly to this "backward world" has the best chance of winning this thinking game.

In game terms
column10470: you lay out a central card that shows the words "up"
column10473: then lay out one picture card on each side of that central card. You then flip over task cards one by one
column10474: and if a task card says "left" you look for the card on the right of the central card; if the task card asks for the name of what lies there
column10475: you instead give the sound it makes. The first person to do so wins the card
column10476:
and whoever collects the most task cards wins the game.

An expert version adds color to the mix
column10477: with both a red and a blue central card
column10478:
and four picture cards around each of those and player needing to look to red whenever the task card calls for blue.

""
column10489: A pattern recognition game. There are 15 large
column10490: sturdy cards depicting an array of various objects such as kites
column10494: etc. Each card shows the same 15 objects
column10495:
but the objects are all different colors and are in different locations. Any two cards always have one and only one object that is identical. Be the first to find this object!

""
column10504: Children's Game involving flipping memory chips onto the board using a catapult
column10505:
then moving robots next to the chip to try and claim it. Each robot has a die underneath which is turned by the action of moving (via ridges on the board.)

""
column10522: A man-to-man medieval combat wargame.  Each side is comprised of peasants
column10526:
and knights. Various scenarios are included in the rules.

Integrates with:

Outremer


The Cry Havoc series page contains information about the game system and history of the game including fan expansions.

""
column10534:
The card game version of the 1989 Spiel des Jahres boardgame "Café International".

Five table cards are laid out to form the "Café". Players then place 1 to 3 guest cards from their hand to the Café scoring points for placement. Bonuses are given if only 1 nationality is seated at a given table. Once a table is full all the guests and the table itself are removed from play and a new table is put in it's place from the table draw pile. Multiple scoring opportunities occur when a guest card is placed between tables with several guests at each.
column10546: A children's trick-taking card game of racing pirate ships around a series of islands to reach the treasure.  The card play is straightforward with four suits
column10548: and following lead suit.  The number of tricks won determines how many spaces a ship moves
column10549: but certain spaces move your ship forward or backward
column10551: or force you to take the long way around an island; therefore
column10552:
there are times when you may not want to win as many tricks as you would be able. Landing on an opponent's ship sends them back to the closest harbor. The first ship to land on the treasure wins!

""
column10565: It's midnight and the dreaded Ghost of MacGregor is haunting the castle.  No one knows which way he'll choose to go as he chases the other players through the halls of the castle. Decide on your best chance for escape
column10566:
but be careful because all of the doors are locked so you'll definitely need the right keys.

The players are trying to be the first to escape the castle before being caught by the ghost. The player controlling the ghost must capture/tag another player if he wants to win. The ghost is moved via 5 preplanned moves each round
column10567: similar to Roborally and Dragon Delta and can move through walls.  The other players must collect the right key cards to move through the colored doors
column10568:
but may only hold four key cards.

If the ghost captures another player
column10569:
they switch roles with the captured player becoming the ghost and moving to the dungeon to start the next round. The former ghost takes the key cards from the new ghost and tries to escape the castle.

Most important: The player figures glow in the dark!

""
column10577: Players alternate placing crown and/or player tiles
column10578: trying to match colors orthogonally.  Perfect matches gain a coin and slightly less than perfect matches have no effect but
column10580:
significantly less than perfect matches carry a severe penalty. Too many missed placements and you're eliminated!

Reimplemented as:

Architekton


(With expanded rules.)

""
column10592: Hyle (or Entropy) is played on a board with 5x5 spaces. During each round one player (Chaos) randomly draws and places colored wooden disks on a vinyl/cloth map. After a disk is placed
column10593: the other player (Order) may move any disk on the grid horizontally or vertically in order to form palindromes (sequences of colors that run the same forward as backward
column10595:
red/blue/yellow/blue/red).

The game is played over two rounds (so that each player assumes each role once) and points are awarded to Order equal to the length of the palindromes formed: blue/blue=2 points
column10597:
etc. (Note that blue/blue/blue is worth 7 points because it contains two 2-point palindromes and one 3-point palindrome.)

Hyle 7 is the same game on a 7x7 grid instead of 5x5.

""
column10609: A fast card-based game with beautiful graphics. Each player manages 3 animals: a lion
column10610:
a gazelle and an hippopotamus. The goal is to move one animal so that it reaches the bar at the top of the board.

To do this
column10611: players must wisely use their action cards. The lion can eat a gazelle
column10612: the hippopotamus can make the lion go back
column10613: and the gazelle can jump very far
column10614:
but not very often.

A player can steal another player cards during the game
column10615:
or spend one of his cards.

""
column10623: Yahtzee meets a board game.  Players move pawns around a board with 12 open spaces and 4 'wild' spaces.  If you land on an open space
column10624: you can try to complete one of the 12 standard Yahtzee combinations (not counting the 'Yahtzee' -- more on that later).  If successful
column10625: you place the card for that combination on the space and a certain number of your chips to signify ownership.  If another player lands on that space later
column10626: they have to match or beat your roll to steal ownership of the board space.  Once a combination has been assigned to a space
column10627: it stays there -- so the number of combinations available to fill a blank space on the board decreases throughout the game.  If a player lands on a 'Wild' space
column10628: they can try for any combination
column10629: then move their piece to the appropriate space and steal ownership.  Also
column10630: if a player gets a Yahtzee
column10631: they can ignore the space they're on and claim ownership of any space on the board.  Once all combinations have been claimed
column10632:
each player gets one more turn in which they're allowed to keep playing as long as they keep stealing ownership of a card. Whoever has the most chips on the board at the end of the game wins. A very interesting twist on the classic Yahtzee mechanism.

""
column10643: The game models the growth and interaction of ancient Civilizations. Each player manages the military
column10644: political and economic aspects of their state
column10645: competing to create the greatest empire in the world.  Disasters such as rebellion
column10646: invasion or civil war may occur at any time -- players must seek an optimal balance between growth and stability to succeed. Although military affairs play an important part in Ancient Empires
column10647: the game is designed so that this aspect does not dominate game play.  Movement and combat are abstracted to a strategic level
column10648: and players will find that timing is just as important as brute strength to avoid counterproductive warfare.  Players must pay equal attention to trade
column10649: diplomacy and internal affairs in order to remain strong enough to discourage aggression. Victory Points are awarded for the size of an empire
column10650:
and the level of development it achieves relative to its peers. Destroyed players retain their Victory Points and may re-enter the game to carve out a new empire.

""
column10660: Boom-O is a simple elimination card game from the makers of Uno. Each player gets 7 cards in hand and three time bomb cards in front of them. Most of the cards in the deck either increase or decrease the timer total. Other cards include familiar commands such as Skip
column10662: Draw 1 (or 2) and Trade Hands. Player discard one card per turn trying to clear their hand while keeping the timer total under 60. If a player can't play a valid card
column10663: they must flip over one of their three time bombs. If a player clears their hand
column10664:
all other players flip one of their time bombs. Whoever flips all three of their bombs is out of the game. Survivor wins.

Re-implements:

5 Alive

""
column10675: [Careful: there are two similar games with Entdecker in the title. Don't confuse Die Neuen Entdecker (also known as Entdecker: Exploring New Horizons) with Entdecker
column10676: a different game. In short - if your Entdecker's board does not have a scout trail leading to native huts
column10677:
it's not this Entdecker.]

A reworking of the game Entdecker
column10678: this game still starts with a blank game board that represents an unexplored sea. Tiles are drawn and placed on squares on the board. As the tiles are placed
column10679: islands develop on the board and players pay to place settlements
column10681:
or scouts on these islands in an effort to become the most powerful explorer.

Completed islands yield victory points to all who have invested in exploration on an island
column10682: but of course the most points go to the player who has established the strongest presence. This updated version adds a larger board
column10683: fees to enter from all but one edge of the board
column10686: the ability to draw (for a price) from open stacks of tiles
column10687: and most of all an entirely new area of the board that represents scouts exploring jungles on the islands in search of exotic plants (this is the bonus discovery chip system revamped)
column10702: Gnadenlos! (Merciless!) is a game in which players enter a prospecting boom town and try to accumulate the most prestige points. Rather than doing the dirty work themselves
column10703: players hire adventurers to pan for their gold
column10705: and sit in for them in the poker games. Since the money hasn't yet come in
column10706: these rough-tough folk are hired merely with pieces of paper - IOUs. But on pay day the IOUs come due
column10707: and if a player can't pay off debts
column10708:
then the vultures swoop in.

Players bid for adventurer cards that will be used in various events - Gold Fever
column10710: and the Poker Game. Each adventurer carries a number (a rating) for each of the three events. When it's time to play out an event
column10711: players place an adventurer card face down. All players simultaneously turn the cards over. The adventurer with the highest number pertaining to the event wins; the lowest loses (ties are usually kept as ties
column10712: with both receiving the benefits or penalties). In Gold Fever the winner and second highest receive gold
column10713: which may be exchanged for prestige points or used to pay off debts. In High Noon
column10714: the winner gets to pick back up two IOUs (not necessarily his or her own); the loser is shot and loses the adventurer card. Also the undertaker advances one space along a timing track. In the Poker Game
column10715: the winner moves forward on the prestige track; the loser moves backwards. The IOU cards used in bids for the adventurers are placed in rows along the board
column10716: each beside one of six dice symbols (showing 1 through 6). When as many rows as there are players in the game are filled
column10717: it's Pay Day. A die is rolled and the outermost card beside the corresponding die symbol is turned up. The player who owns that IOU must pay up. This continues until either all cards of one die symbol have been turned up
column10718:
or a player cannot meet a debt. The unfortunate player in this case gets a vulture chip and moves back 5 spaces on the prestige track. The game ends either when one player has 3 vulture chips; a player reaches or passes the winning space on the prestige track; or the undertaker reaches his final space. When the game ends the player farthest along the prestige track wins.

""
column10728: 'Eden is the dream of making arid land fertile. At the outset
column10729: the board is a desert. Players play irrigation cards that allow them to place plant tiles in the desert
column10730: thus bringing life and fertility to it. As the desert grows
column10731: cultivation cards may develop the plant tiles further
column10732: making them more valuable and bringing players much manna. The player who first gets tiles valued at 20 "fertility points" on the board wins. But watch out! As the desert blooms competition for the land increases
column10733:
and other players will try to take your most fertile land away.

The game play in Eden is simple. Either play one or two irrigation cards to develop areas of desert (i.e. place tiles on the board)
column10734: or play a cultivation card to increase the value of areas already on the board (i.e. replace existing tiles with more valuable ones
column10736: or pass. Conflict enters the game when a player places a new tile on the board next to an opponent's existing tile. Then a challenge may be made by the player placing the tile. Manna
column10739: which takes the form of a bidding war. Bids
column10741: are always increased. But what the winning bidder actually must pay is the bid MULTIPLIED by the value of the tiles that would be gained. In the case of the challenger
column10742: the winning bid would be the bid itself times the value of the tiles sought. In the case of the defender
column10743: the winning bid would be the bid itself times the value of the tiles the defender is using in what in effect is an attack. Bids keep rising until one player is unwilling
column10745: to meet the final cost of a bid. The loser forfeits all the tiles involved in the conflict
column10746:
but gains the value of that land (according to the bid) in manna from the other player.

""
column10757: Traboulet has marbles to be pushed singly or in rows along an open 7x7 grid of holes. Each player has two clusters of four marbles each in opposite corners. Thirteen red neutral marbles in diamond shape start in the center of the grid. Players can push on any open end of their marbles to push the neutral or opposing marbles off the edge. Every time a player pushes a marble off the edge
column10758:
they get to move again. First player to push off 7 red marbles or all of his opponent's movable marbles wins.

column10768: In early 20th century Germany players are competing to build efficient rail networks to carry goods. But this costs a lot of money
column10769: so borrowing is heavy. Players have to be careful to borrow only as much as they need to bid for turn order
column10771:
and move goods. At the end of each turn dividends (interest) on the bonds come due. Those who can't pay lose some of their hard-earn cash.

""
column10789: In many ways "Dungeon!" is similar to Dungeons & Dragons
column10790: although much simplified and transformed into a board game. Players explore a dungeon that is divided into levels of increasing difficulty
column10791: fighting monsters for valuable treasure. As players venture deeper into the dungeon
column10792: the monsters become more difficult and the treasure more valuable. Several character classes each have slightly different fighting abilities – most notably the wizard
column10793: who can cast spells. Combat is simulated using dice; players roll the dice to attack a monster
column10795:
the dice are rolled to determine the effect of the monster's counter-attack.

The winner is the first player to bring a certain amount of treasure back to the Dungeon's entrance.

Reimplemented by:


The Classic Dungeon
The New Dungeon


""
column10807: Doubloon Lagoon is a game of exploration
column10809:
and chase. Players search for a lost treasure and attempt to return to their homeport with the treasure before the other players can stop them.

Seventy-five custom imaged cards allow players to execute effects and damage their opponents with Tornados
column10811:
Priate attacks and other surprises.

Players can explore islands with their crews or go for a straight attack on their opponents to eliminate them before they find the treasure. The varieties and combinations of strategies allow for many replay's.

""
column10819: A plastic cribbage board like no other

column10822: shortcuts and setbacks that the players must follow if they land on certain spaces via play
column10823: hand or crib count. Use strategy to avoid the traps and utilize the advances. Crib Wars takes a lot longer to play than cribbage so beware
column10824:
the official rules forbid you to quit!

column10843: Players are historical 'wise men' in 13th C wandering across Europe piecing together information in a quest to find the Holy Grail. Players accumulate scraps of information from various obscure texts
column10844: trading information with other wandering scholars they may find
column10845: all the time trying to manage limited resources and avoid disasters in the form of bandits
column10863: In Genoa (originally published as The Traders of Genoa)
column10864: players take the part of Renaissance traders
column10865: moving about the city acquiring goods and filling orders for goods. Messages need to be delivered and privileges obtained. Of course
column10866:
none of this can be accomplished on one's own. Much negotiation and deal-making is the order of the day in an effort to become the richest deal-maker in Genoa. Flexible rules allow for negotiating almost everything in the game.

The Traders of Genoa version of this game is #6 in the Alea big box series.

""
column10876: Crazy Race is one of three Spiele aus Timbuktu games with a common train theme
column10877:
along with Mogul and Station Manager. The boxes even fit together to make a common picture.

Players race three Creatures on a track from a start/finish line

11 are rated as "even").

Games requiring SGBOH playbook

Games that are not supported by SGBOH

- Lion of the North
- War Galley
- Caesar in Alexandria - but it is very SGBOH-like apparently
- Siege of Alesia

Contents:

- Simple Great Battles of History Rules (Nov. 2004 edition has updates for several scenarios)
- Simple Great Battles of History Charts
- Simple Great Battles of History Playbook containing SGBOH scenarios for Alexander
column10907:
Conquest of Gaul and Cataphract.

column10919: The players are adventurers seeking gold in an abandoned mine. Each ventures into the mine equipped with a lantern (with a limited amount of oil). The outer ring of hexes can be searched for additional equipment (torches
column10921: mushrooms...) whilst the inner hexes are where the gold is to be found. First player to bring back six gold nuggets wins. Or
column10923:
the player whose spider has scored the most kills wins...
Finding gold isn't as easy as it seems; the richest hexes (smack in the mine's center
column10924:
of course) only yield gold on a 4+ (on a d6); using the lantern gives a +1.
Where it gets really fun is with the mine's other denizens: each player controls
column10926: a spider that hops from rock column to rock column (the pivot points where hexes meet; the board is 3D so this works really well) spinning webs --little cardboard barriers that slide into place between rock pillars. Adventurers "attack" the webs when they try to step through and could stay tangled (the adventurer pieces are slotted so they can be put on top of the web they're stuck in). Whilst thus caught
column10927:
spiders can try to bite them --four bites and you're eliminated! The lantern is very useful in such a case as its light scares the spiders away.
The spiders can co-operate to build stronger webs
column10928:
and it isn't unusual for one spider to strengthen the web an adventurer is caught in so another spider has a better chance of biting him.
All in all
column10929:
a very enjoyable game. Works best with the full set of six players.

Each turn energy stones are removed from the spell cards

column10998: Time's Up! is a charades-based party game for teams of two or more players (and is best with teams of two). Before the game begins
column10999: each player looks at several cards featuring famous historical or fictional characters and chooses some of them. Each player's cards are shuffled to form a deck
column11000:
and this deck of famous names is used for each of the game's three rounds.

In each round
column11001: team members take turns trying to get their teammates to guess as many names as possible in 30 seconds. In round 1
column11002: almost any kind of clue is allowed
column11003: and the cluegiver cannot pass on a card. In round 2
column11004: no more than one word can be used in each clue (but unlimited sounds and gestures are permitted); the cluegiver can pass on any card he likes
column11005: and the teammates can give only a single answer. In round 3
column11006: the cluegiver can use no words at all and can pass as often as he likes; again
column11007: teammates are allowed only a single guess. Give good physical clues in round 1
column11008:
and they'll pay dividends down the road when you need to keep your mouth shut and gesture like a maniac before time's up!

Time's Up! is based on the public domain game known as Celebrities. Also known as Salad Bowl or Fish Bowl.
