column21944:
Ages 7 and up

"A fiendish game of suspense and fun! Players plot their escape from Dracula's castle and move stealthily towards the exit. But beware! Dracula prowls the castle looking for a victim..."

The first player to suffer Dracula's bite becomes the "green vampire" and dons the green vampire's face mask. This vampire then flits from room to room
column21945:
seeking another victim to take over his role. Any further victims of Dracula go back to the vault and must attempt their escape from square one again. The Dracula and Green Vampire pieces actually engulf the players' playing pieces when they're "bitten".

A simple
column21960:
This game is a geopolitical simulation of local influence in the Middle East on the flow of oil supplies to the rest of the world.

The map shows 8 fictitious Middle Eastern oil producing countries
column21961: one of which controls the Canal that links both ocean sides. If your superpower is on one ocean and you try to obtain oil from a country bordering on the other ocean
column21962: the Canal becomes of vital strategic importance. The alternative is to connect that country to another on the "correct" side of the board (through the land-locked middle countries
column21963: which are also bigger producers) with a series of pipelines. To move oil you must
column21965:
have a friendly leader in place at the head of that country.

You start with a leader of your color on the capital of a country and one tanker that can transport oil from that country's port to your country. To reflect a level of organisation
column21966: oil is worth more per shipping if a king or politician is in place than a dictator or guerrilla
column21967: whose job is more offensive. You spend money to move leader pieces about the board
column21968: with the managing pieces costing more than the offensive pieces. Secret agents also move each turn and are used to defend attacks by blocking the path of opposing leaders and for moving onto "?" spaces to take a gamble on an incident card. At face value
column21969: half the cards are favourable and half not
column21970:
but all offer diplomatic opportunities for the country who is most stable.

To survive players must continually manage risks while trying to maximize their oil revenue. Early bold attacks
column21971: even combined with the right incident card
column21972:
are not recommended: a co-operative approach to the game maximises revenue to offset the many accidents which can happen in the game.

From the Waddington ad for the game dated 1972:

A political strategy game
"In the modern world of international diplomacy and intrigue
column21973:
there are many stakes in this game of economic survival. That means energy and the key to energy is oil. In this game there is but one object - and that is to survive"

column22006:
Theme
5 Alive is an abstract card-playing game.

Goal
Each player starts with 5 lives. The winner is the last player to have any lives left.

Gameplay
Each player in turn plays a card from their hand. 'Normal' cards have a face value
column22007: and the aim is not to play a card that takes the running total above 21. If you do
column22008: you lose a life. If you manage to play the last card from your hand without taking the total above 21
column22009: then every other player loses a life. As well as 'normal' cards
column22010: there is also a variety of 'wild' cards that perform special actions
column22013:
reversing the direction of play or causing other players to draw extra cards.

Components
108 cards & instructions

Boom-O

column22057: Not to be confused with Campaign
column22058:
the identically named game produced by Wills and Hepworth in the 1940's.

"An exciting strategy game in which each player can become a Napoleon or a Wellington leading his army across Europe. Famous battles can be re-fought and alliances can be made and broken with this compelling game of military and political strategy"

Large playing board in three sections
column22059: four sets of army pieces in red
column22063: 9 infantry and 9 cavalry units.  Six sets of 4 town cards of different colors
column22067:
and a 4 page "The Years of Napoleon" historical booklet.

The game reproduces the Napoleonic wars at the strategic level in a very abstract fashion (all players are equal). It can be won either by the outright defeat of your opponent
column22068: or (more likely) by acquiring towns controlling large areas of territory.  The board is an abstract representation of Europe and western Russia and is divided into six areas of roughly equal size representing France
column22072:
Italy and Spain.

Each country has four provincial towns
column22073: and five of the countries used as starting countries also have a capital city.  Parts of the board
column22077:
and sea which restrict the movement of the troops.

There are introductory and standard rules. Normally
column22079:
but in the two player game each gets two countries except that the France + Prussia combo is not allowed.

The pieces move using the dice
column22080: and combat is deterministic.  The throw can be used all on one piece or many pieces.  The full throw does not have to be used.  The pieces are placed in a set format on the country selected
column22081:
with the General on the capital square and four infanty and four cavalry. The town cards are used to keep track of who controls what.

The pieces move in set ways. The General moves one square in any direction. When it attacks it has a value of one and when defending a value of two. The General must be present to take a town. Cavalry moves two squares at a time and must move horizontally or vertically but never diagonally. Infantry moves one square and only diagonally. Pieces cannot pass through opposing lines unless there is a clear gap of at least one square.

Combat is like movement: one considers which pieces could be moved to the target piece's square and totals up the combat value --if large enough
column22082: the opposing piece is removed.  Only one piece can be attacked in a turn.  In the standard game
column22083: adjacent pieces also support each other (in a manner reminiscent of Diplomacy)
column22084:
which introduces a fair amount of tactics in on-going battles.

Lost pieces are regenerated in your country's mustering area
column22085: forcing you to keep a constant flow of recruits towards the front.  In the standard game
column22086:
the towns also represent logistical support --lose the town and you lose the corresponding piece.

The odd movement system means you actually have two sets of cavalry and infantry pieces on the board
column22087:
each set (which we could call "odd" and "even") being unable to assist the other.

A capital can only be captured after the provincial towns have been captured. Where more than two players are playing you can agree to ally with another player and exchange alliance cards as reminders. An ally cannot cross into his ally's territory without his consent. Alliances can be broken simply by announcing the fact; you can attack your former ally on your next turn only
column22088:
giving him a turn to re-deploy.

The game is won if the player captures all his opponents capitals or captures 8 towns of any colour but not including the 4 in his own country. You also win if your opponent's General is left with no troops.

Campaign is basically a pure strategy game. It you are in a position to attack a piece
column22090:
there is some luck depending on how high a movement throw you have.

from the Waddington ad for the game from 1976: "This absorbing strategy game captures the tension and the pressures of the famous Napoleonc battles. Alliances are made and broken and complex manoevers bring victory or defeat"

column22424: In this highly abstract strategic wargame
column22425: you are trying to conquer China by being the first to occupy fifteen provinces at the completion of a complete round of play (all players having had an equal number of turns).  Alternatively
column22426:
the game can be timed and scored.

You start with a small number of provinces under your control. Population counters of your colour indicate this; if a province has extra population
column22427: it can move some into an adjacent unoccupied province --this is the simplest way of conquest.  Merger
column22428: diplomacy and force (Risk-like combat) are your other options.  Each turn you draw a Yin card and a Yang card.  Yin is bad
column22429: Yang is good.  Without looking at either card's instructions
column22430: you assign them to two of your provinces.  Yang will most likely increase your recruitment (which is normally three population per turn)
column22431:

A player may attempt to convince another player to merge with his empire. If the second player agrees then the smaller empire is absorbed by the larger and both players continue play as senior (larger) and junior (smaller) partners. The absorbed empire no longer has a separate turn nor separate recruitment. This concept of "shared victory" is intriguing

particularly with a larger number of players.

An instructive game about the environment and it's influence.

Year of publication is 1995 by "Foundation The Natural Path". Came into Guinness Book of Records after been played simultaneously by 47160 students and teachers in the category "most players of the same game during one day".

otherwise you step down. You also get a money reward for correct answers.

When you have collected enough money

to mark that they are handled.
